Australians, as they always have, will regard the Indonesian people as their friends, and the relationship will endure beyond this particular crisis. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the motion on East Timor that was brought into the House by the Prime Minister. In doing so I know I have the full support of the people in my electorate of Cook. One thing that has impressed me, having been the member for Cook since the election last October, is that on this issue I have received more phone calls than on any other issue since I have been a member.

speech.para: It is also interesting that the particular electorate I represent has 78 per cent Australian-born constituents and 93 per cent of Anglo-Celtic background. So my electorate is not one which is highly ethnic in nature, but rather it represents middle Australia. To have that level of support to show to our near neighbours has encouraged me. Overwhelmingly, the recommendation that has been made to me is that we should support the Timorese wholeheartedly in their efforts for independence.

The first aspect of the motion was the overwhelming choice for independence exercised by the East Timorese people on 30 August. As a nation, Australia values its democratic traditions, its history and the whole environment in which we live and we look to our East Timorese neighbours and say, `What an amazing situation.' These people were under personal attack. Their houses were being burnt and their personal safety was being jeopardised. Yet they stood out in the sun, with their personal identification photos and cards, to be counted as part of the vote. Despite the difficulties, the pressure and the history, they were going to record their vote come what may.

The level of the vote—there were 98.5 per cent who actually registered for the vote—is overwhelming, even by Australian standards. Given the pressure that was on the East Timorese, it is remarkable indeed. It is because of that fact that these people were expressing their own hope for independence. It has been a long and difficult period, not the least of which has been Australia's own involvement in East Timor. We came into that land in 1942—which actually coincides with the date of my birth. Australia has been involved for a long period. We were concerned that the Japanese were going to invade that area and use it as a base to attack Australia. Subsequently, we withdrew from that area and they had to put up with attacks from the Japanese who invaded East Timor.

Following that, in East Timor in 1975, we saw the invasion by Indonesia. Australia remained silent during that period. We actually endorsed the Indonesian acquisition of the territory and never uttered any protest. Of course, it is very easy to look back, and I must admit my own personal liability in this regard. We did not regard the issue as being significant as far as we were concerned, and I did not lend my voice to the concerns of many people about the situation of the East Timorese.

So today, these people, who have been through so much, have voted overwhelmingly for freedom, for independence. We can only stand back in amazement at the actual persecution they endured to reach that stage. But they have voted for independence and it behoves us as they are our close neighbours and because of their history—part of which is somewhat unfortunate in terms of our relationship with that country—and it is appropriate that we take part in the United Nations peacekeeping force and lead the delegation into East Timor at a very difficult time. Obviously, there are security problems involved and risks to the Australian troops, but they go in the best Anzac tradition. We have seen a great resurgence in terms of support for the Anzac tradition. At the early morning service on Anzac Day that was held in my own electorate, they had record numbers. We recognise the sacrifices of the generations before us.

Now we have our own generation who are involved in the conflict in Timor, who are representing us in that place, who are part of a force that comes from Thailand, the Philippines, Malaysia, Korea, the USA and Britain. We have become part of the United Nations resolution 1264, which authorised a multinational force to restore peace and security and protect the United Nations mission in East Timor and facilitate humanitarian assistance. It is appropriate we do and I am sure all Australians support this effort.
Of course this is a sensitive time. In his book, Australian Foreign Policy, former foreign affairs minister Gareth Evans wrote that in terms of achieving adherence to human rights standards:
. . . blunt statements are usually not as effective as repeated, deliberately quiet entreaties.

I have heard many careless and blunt statements made in this debate without recognition of the sensitivities of our relationship with Indonesia or of the work that has gone on in the past to assist East Timor. This damages our effectiveness in realising our goals in this sensitive international arena.

President Habibie gave the option for an independence vote. Ideally, we should have had a greater amount of time in order to secure peace in the province. The decision to hold the ballot is a great achievement. It is a decision which President Habibie should be congratulated on. We should be sensitive to the political pressures he is under. He did not create the East Timor problem, but rather he inherited it. There was no way of knowing how strongly independent the military is of the government. We can only make our own assessments as to how important they are in the overall equation to ensure the stability of the Indonesian government. We must be careful in the types of statements that are made.

Australia could not move in peacekeepers earlier. The whole rhetoric that `We should have done more; we should have done this' ignores the fact that on 5 May the agreement was made between Portugal and Indonesia to hold an independence ballot, and it specified that Indonesia would maintain security. Offers of peacekeeping on our part were rejected. We would have hardly wished to engage the 260,000-strong coercive force in direct military conflict. That is what would have resulted had a peacekeeping force been forced upon Indonesia. Without Indonesia's agreement there was no prospect for UN or other regional peacekeeping.

The debate has also focused on the question of defence funding. In recent times, defence funding has focused more on hardware than on the number of troops the ADF has at its disposal. It is right that, in this period of lasting peace, Australia should find other priorities, and it is true that we now have the smallest number of personnel under arms since 1962, but the nature of the approaches to the Australian continent dictates that our focus should be on such issues as arming our submarines with cruise missiles and upgrading our F111 planes to allow in-flight refuelling.

There is also no validity to the argument that Australia could have done more to pressure the United States or the international community. Our diplomatic efforts are unmatched by other nations. We are the only country to have diplomatic representation in East Timor, and we have never missed an opportunity to discuss East Timor. The United States has been fully apprised of the intelligence Australia has had on East Timor.

It is with pleasure that I support this motion before the House. We do endorse the great stand taken by the East Timorese people on their decision to vote for independence from Indonesia. We welcome the United Nations security team and the fact that it is being led by an Australian group. We endorse the United Nations decision to send in a peacekeeping force. We also, as a parliament, as a country, and as parliamentarians who fully support our troops as part of the peacekeeping force, say that we are totally and absolutely with them. We uphold that great Australian tradition. We certainly look forward to their safe return and hope that it is without incident. We know that they go bearing with them the great wishes of Australia. We look forward to a time when both Indonesians and East Timorese can live in a situation which is one of peace in the region.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to have an opportunity to speak in this debate on a motion to take note of United Nations Security Council resolution 1264, authorising a multinational force to restore peace and security in East Timor, protect the United Nations mission in East Timor and facilitate humanitarian assistance. I have been particularly saddened by the events that have occurred in East Timor over the past few months. As members may be aware, I was honoured to be part of the international observer mission to the general elections which were held in Indonesia at the beginning of June. My participation in that as one of 500 overseas observers who were working in conjunction with domestic monitors from Indonesia led me to be inspired by the process and optimistic in the lead-up to the referendum in East Timor.

speech.para: During the Indonesian elections there was a lot of talk about the possible corruption of the system and the violence that might occur, and some of that violence did occur in areas such as Ambon and Aceh. However, in the main, the Indonesian general election went very smoothly for the first fair and free elections that that country had held. The Indonesian people spoke out at that time overwhelmingly in favour of a change in government, in favour of ousting the Golkar party from power and welcoming a new political party into power in Indonesia. I came back from that exercise optimistic and inspired, hoping that the same result might have occurred in East Timor during the referendum.

I cannot reflect on what could have been done, should have been done or may have been done. I cannot reflect on whether we should have sent in peacekeepers earlier or whether there should have been more international presence in East Timor in the lead-up to the referendum and following it. What I can say is that at the moment there is a multinational force in East Timor to try to enforce peace, to try to protect the East Timorese people, and, even though it may be too little too late, it is a step which Australia has taken in the right direction.

During the Indonesian general election the people spoke out to change the government without fear of reprisals, in much the same way that the United Nations and Australia encouraged the East Timorese people to vote in their referendum. We encouraged them to turn out to register to vote in the referendum, which they did in droves. We encouraged them to turn out to vote in the referendum, which they did in droves. As we know, that vote was overwhelmingly for independence of East Timor.

We and the United Nations said, prior to the referendum, `We are here to assist you. We will stay with you throughout the vote and we will protect you after the vote has been counted.' The East Timorese people placed their trust in the United Nations but I believe that the international community failed the East Timorese people. People of any nation should never be subjected to the atrocities that reportedly have been inflicted upon the East Timorese people for voting for independence and participating in a democratic process. But finally Australia and the international community rose to speak out against these atrocities that were being committed in East Timor. I would just like to reflect on some of those actions which have taken place in our communities.

On 9 September this year, we held a meeting in the Newcastle Town Hall. It was initiated by the Lord Mayor, Greg Heys. There were various speakers, including the Anglican bishop, Roger Herft; the Catholic bishop, Michael Malone; the federal member for Newcastle, Allan Morris; the Newcastle Trades Hall Council Secretary, Peter Barrack; the state member for Newcastle, Bryce Gaudry; and Sister Carmel Hansen from Caritas. Sister Carmel had been working alongside the Caritas sisters in East Timor. She said that about 40 minutes prior to her coming to speak to the packed Newcastle Town Hall, she had heard that a sister that she had been working closely with and had made very good friends with, had been hacked to death with a machete in East Timor. She chose to share her emotions with us at that time.

We were also spoken to by Stephen O'Brien, another local Hunter Valley person, who was a volunteer district electoral officer in East Timor, and Stephen Tickner, a media photographer who had recently been in East Timor. They both recounted some of the atrocities and the violence that they had witnessed. That meeting at the Newcastle Town Hall was packed, as I am sure other town halls right across the country were as public meetings were held, and Australians stood arm in arm together and spiritually side by side with the East Timorese people.

On 10 September, another meeting held in my area was of the Retired Mineworkers Association of the Northern District. I would like to mention a resolution which the Retired Mineworkers Association, Northern District delegates conveyed to the Prime Minister on that day, following their meeting. They urged the United Nations to urgently dispatch a peacekeeping force to East Timor to oversee and facilitate a peacekeeping process. They also called upon the trade union movement to exercise its ability to impose sanctions against the Indonesian government while the Indonesian government was seemingly not supporting, or not inviting, an international peacekeeping force.

The MUA in Newcastle was the first group of trade unionists which placed sanctions against loading Indonesian vessels in the port of Newcastle. This delayed the loading of the ships for nearly two weeks. Patrick, which was the force behind the attacks on the unions early last year, supported their stance, indicating that any trade unionist who was involved in employing sanctions against Indonesian vessels during this time would not be penalised at all under the current Workplace Relations Act.

An article in the Sun-Herald on 12 September described the international world trade union movement consolidating a campaign to impose sanctions, both economic and political, against Indonesia and the Indonesian government. This is just another message about the way that, when people are in trouble—whether they be workers, downtrodden citizens of another country or people being denied their participation in a democratic process—they are supported by trade unionists in all countries right across the world and across all industry bases. The international trade union organisation vowed to end the massacres and enforce the sovereign decision of the East Timor people and of the United Nations. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Coming at this stage in the debate in this committee and in the main chamber after so many speakers, I guess it is going to be very difficult to say anything that may be new or have more impact than all of the things that have been said before. Nonetheless, I can understand why other speakers from both sides have been talking about this issue and why I feel impelled to talk about it as well. It is something of great importance not only to Australia but also to our region and the world as a whole. I have to say that I have never known so many people in my electorate to be so concerned and so upset about any particular issue. In the days when things were consolidating, virtually every time there was a television news broadcast of some of the disgraceful, horrifying and atrocious things that were happening I would have grown men and women calling me in tears because of their emotional response to those news telecasts.

speech.para: The response was one of pity and sympathy for the East Timorese. It seemed that people's judgment was overcome very often by their emotion and by their concern. I can understand that. I had one man ring me in tears demanding that we, as the government, should just go and bomb Jakarta that night. This was never an option. A number of people rang and said, `The government is doing nothing. You are not talking to anybody. You are not talking to the Indonesians, the United Nations, the Americans, the Malaysians or anybody.' This was totally untrue because the government was doing everything it possibly could in an endeavour to put together a solution to the situation which we now see, with the United Nations resolution of 15 September being put into effect with a multinational force led by Australia.

We need to point out that this is only a temporary situation. Stage 2 will be a United Nations peacekeeping force with blue berets or blue helmets. We would expect that Australia will be part of that, but it will be led by the United Nations. We are acting on the basis of a United Nations Security Council resolution passed unanimously, which is quite amazing, in the shortest time that anything of that nature has ever taken place with regard to a similar peacekeeping force.

With the greatest respect to my friends in the opposition on the other side of the chamber, not all of them but too many of them have used this particular issue as a little political whipping boy to attack the government. I am sorry that they did that because I believe that the government did everything that possibly could be done.

I want to say, too, that we are not at odds with the Indonesian people; we are at odds with the atrocious things that happened in East Timor. We felt obliged to take the action that we did. We had to lead in the formation of the United Nations force, but it should be clearly understood that we have no argument with the Indonesian people as such. It is perhaps difficult for them to understand at this stage and I can understand that we may suffer in terms of our trade relations; nonetheless, whatever the outcome, we had to take the action that we did.

There is one issue that is not germane to this but it is relevant in my mind, and that is—as has been said time and time again and the Prime Minister said it only today—every government of Australia up to the present time has not acted as we would, in retrospect, wished they had acted in regard to East Timor.

The issue I want to throw in as another matter concerns West Papua, West Irian. We have not spoken in this parliament very much about West Irian since I have been here. But just as the issue of East Timor was a thorn in the side of so many of us because of our inaction when that invasion of East Timor by the Indonesians happened, I have to say to this committee and to the House in general that, for me, it has been a thorn in my side too that Australia did nothing when the Indonesians took over West Irian. We should remember that the island of Papua New Guinea was, in 1848, divided into three to carve it up between the Germans, the British and the Dutch. Of course, in World War I we liberated—to use the modern word—the German colony of New Guinea, we got the mandate over it from the League of Nations and it is now an independent country. But in 1848, over 150 years ago, that island was carved up.

On 1 October 1962, post World War II, the Dutch government handed over their former colony of West Papua to an interim United Nations administration. I will not go into great detail on this because I have a lot more I want to say about East Timor. But West Papua was a Cold War sacrifice—it was a sacrifice to the aims and the objects of the Cold War participants. On 1 May 1963, Indonesia became the new colonial power in west Papua New Guinea and we did nothing about it. I regret to say that it was in the time of the government of former Prime Minister John Gorton and we did nothing about it, and I do not believe the Labor opposition at that time did anything about it either. I think it is to our eternal shame that not only did we not protest about the invasion of East Timor, but that we sat back and did nothing about the fate of the West Papuans.

To come back to East Timor and, in particular, to our forces there, I have to say that I am so full of admiration and pride for the way they are conducting themselves. I have the greatest sympathy for their families, their loved ones, at home. Like everybody in this house of parliament, we all pray and hope that nobody will be seriously injured or killed. We cannot guarantee it, unfortunately, in this situation. But the message that we have to send to those Australian men and women who are serving in East Timor at the moment is that the whole of Australia is proud of them and what they are doing.

I will not run off a list of all the countries that are participating, but it is more than encouraging that there have been so many countries which have come forward to say they will participate in one way or another—some with troops, some with ships, some just with money. It is worth noting that the Security Council resolution was unanimous. China was one of the members of the Security Council which voted for the resolution, and that is pretty significant. I was in China the week before last and it was in their news that China had agreed to send a small group of civilian policemen to participate in the peacekeeping task. It does not matter that it is small. It is the very first time, I believe, that China has participated in any one of these peacekeeping forces or activities. I think it says an enormous amount for the correctness of what is going on.

It is such a pity that the militia in East Timor—or from West Timor—have behaved in the way that they have. I do not think that anybody witnessing that film footage will ever forget it; I know I certainly will not. It is up to the Indonesian government to realise that it has let down the people of East Timor. The army were there as peacekeepers, even under martial law, and they did nothing—I would find it very difficult to be convinced otherwise. They just let the militias run amok. It is also a great shame for Indonesia that they apparently allowed their troops, their people, to raze Dili and other areas to the ground to destroy the infrastructure, which will make it so much more difficult for the free, independent country of East Timor to emerge. Long-term, Australia's aim must be to assist that new country to emerge in a free, democratic manner, and we should give every assistance we can, once the emergency is over, to provide the East Timorese people with assistance to let them go forward in freedom and peace into democracy.

talk.start.para: —I am grateful for the opportunity to participate in this debate tonight, and in doing so, I thought I might give a brief report of a couple of public meetings in my electorate of Bendigo, which have taken place in the previous two weeks. The first one was a meeting in Castlemaine on 7 September, which was called at one day's notice; approximately 90 people attended that meeting. The second meeting was a few short days later in Bendigo, again at short notice, and some 120 people from the Bendigo district attended that meeting. That meeting, incidentally, was called by the city of Greater Bendigo. This not only highlights the depth of feeling that people in Bendigo have over this issue, but I am sure it is reflected in communities all over Australia. I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard the resolutions carried at those meetings.

speech.para: Leave granted.
The resolutions read as follows—
East Timor Meeting Castlemaine—Tuesday, September 7, 1999.
At a public meeting held in Castlemaine, Victoria, called at one day's notice, 86 people attended and passed the following motion unanimously:

That this meeting demands the immediate and complete withdrawal of Indonesian Armed Forces from East Timor to be immediately replaced by a Peacekeeping force made up of Australian and/or United Nations Forces.
Until Indonesian Forces agree to leave East Timor, we demand that the Australian Government implement the following actions:
1 A complete trade embargo on all trade with Indonesia.
2 Halt all financial assistance to the Government of Indonesia.
3 Immediately desist from training members of the Indonesian Armed Forces in Sale or any other Australian Bases.
4 The mobilisation of Australian Military forces to give armed support and protection to the People of East Timor as they move towards their democratic choice of independence.

REPORT OF THE PUBLIC MEETING CALLED BY THE MAYOR OF THE CITY OF GREATER BENDIGO, CR. DARYL McCLURE TO PROVIDE AN OPPORTUNITY FOR BENDIGO PEOPLE TO EXPRESS THEIR SUPPORT FOR THE PEOPLE OF EAST TIMOR FOLLOWING THE HAVOC WREAKED BY ARMED PRO-INDONESIA MILITIAS FOLLOWING A BALLOT WHICH RESULTED IN AN OVERWHELMING MAJORITY IN FAVOUR OF CUTTING TIES WITH INDONESIA.
The meeting commenced at 6.00 p.m. and was attended by approximately 120 Bendigo citizens.
The meeting was addressed by Mr Victor Kaye, who had recently returned East Timor, after serving with the United Nations Assistance Mission to East Timor.
The following resolutions were passed by the meeting:
That this meeting of Bendigo citizens request:

1 That the Prime Minister, the Honourable John Howard and the Foreign Minister, the Honourable Alexander Downer, express our outrage on behalf of the Australian Government to the Government and Military of Indonesia, and their failure to meet their obligations of protection and security for the East Timorese people as defined by the United Nations Agreement of the 5th May 1999.
2 That a PeaceKeeping Force be deployed in East Timor and trade sanctions be imposed on Indonesia forthwith.
3 That the Government be urged to use its influence with the International Monetary Fund and World Bank to withhold all monetary assistance to Indonesia immediately.

4 That Bendigo people and businesses be urged to boycott Indonesian products and suspend all dealings with Indonesia until continuing peace and freedom is established in East Timor and all East Timorese have control of their own destiny in accordance with the United Nations 5th May, 1999 Agreements.

5 That the recommended action expressed in the letter from Amnesty International be endorsed which requests the sending of telegrams/telexes/faxes/express/airmail letters, making the following points:
(a) Expressing your horror at the situation in East Timor, and your fears for the safety of the entire population;

(b) Noting that the United Nations is a party to the 5 May 1999 Agreements, and has an obligation to the East Timorese people, who, despite threats and intimidation, courageously exercised their right to self-determined by participating in the popular consultation on 30 August 1999;
(c) Asking what, as a member state of the United Nations, your Government is doing to protect the rights of the East Timorese people;

(d) Urging your Government to impose an immediate moratorium on all transfers to Indonesia of military, security and police equipment, weaponry, personnel or training which could be used by the army, police or militias to commit human rights violations. The moratorium should include all financial and logistical support for such transfers, including spare parts and maintenance, licensed production, brokering and Government-to-Government agreements;
and that trade sanctions be imposed.
6 That it be recognised that the resolutions made are aimed at the Government and the military of Indonesia, rather than the Indonesian people.
7 That there be an immediate and safe return of all East Timorese who have been forcibly removed to Indonesia.
8 That the Federal Government be advised that the Bendigo community stands ready to provide whatever humanitarian aid it can to assist those affected by the civil strife in East Timor.
A collection was taken up to aid the people of East Timor. Funds would be distributed by Victor Kaye, through the United Nations Assistance Mission to East Timor.
The Mayor and Council were thanked for arranging the public meeting.
A small group of people arranged to meet after the meeting to arrange a candlelight vigil and rally.
The meeting concluded at 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —The guest speaker at both meetings was a man named Mr Victor Kaye, who is a resident of Castlemaine in Bendigo. Mr Kaye was in East Timor as a United Nations observer at the recent election, and made it back to Castlemaine on Monday, 6 September. Ironically, Mr Kaye said, the election day was quite peaceful. When he arrived at the guesthouse he was to stay in, an eight-year-old boy played his guitar and performed a song for him. The boy politely refused Mr Kaye's offer of 500 rupiah, or about $A1, for performing the song by saying, `I do it for you.' Such is the generous nature of the East Timorese people.

speech.para: But, as Mr Kaye reported, there were ominous undertones beneath the surface of normality. Violence erupted in the area he was staying in on the Friday, when the house Mr Kaye was staying in was fired upon. He and others who were staying in the home, including judges from the International Commission of Jurists, had to flee for their lives. The house opposite had exploded and was burnt out. The group fled to a second house and then a third house in the one night, dodging shots and being pursued by armed militia. Mr Kaye slept on the bare floor, rather than risk sleeping on a mattress, in case a fire bomb was thrown in.

Outside, the streets turned to chaos, with incidents which made Mr Kaye sick to his stomach. He reported on a situation where a soldier ripped a three-year-old child out of the arms of its father, wringing its neck and throwing it into a burning house. Such were the activities being pursued by the militia. As Mr Kaye said, these people are not soldiers, they are dogs.

On Saturday morning, Mr Kaye and his group managed to get a spot on a vessel which was due to depart East Timor. But as they departed, about 15 shots were fired at the vessel from the wharf. When the boat docked in the West Timorese harbour, the group was told to stay aboard for some hours, and then they realised that they would be taken away for interrogation. Again in fear of their lives, they grabbed their bags and barged through the armed militia guarding the wharf. `Just a few days later, we would not have been able to do that,' Mr Kaye said. `We were in mortal danger.' The group escaped into the streets and eventually made it back to the airport and back to Australia.

That is a snapshot of the experiences of one man who has been very active in East Timorese affairs for some years and who was, as I said, over there as an observer in the elections. Man's inhumanity to man has never ceased to shock or amaze me. The stories relayed by Mr Kaye, and indeed the horrific pictures we see on our news bulletins, show that what has happened in East Timor is probably one of the most barbaric acts we have witnessed in our region.

Last Sunday week, I attended the arrival of the second wave of refugees to the Puckapunyal safe haven, along with the member for McEwen, who is the patron. I remember standing at the door of the bus, helping the people off it, and seeing the looks of absolute despair on their faces, especially the elderly and the young kids. It was probably one of the most traumatic experiences of my life and something I will probably not forget for some time.

As I mentioned before, we have seen horrific footage coming through on our television screens each night. Obviously, equally barbaric is the action of the Indonesian military as they withdrew from the province and burn and pillage everything that is left. Whilst the Indonesian people cannot be held responsible for that, their military certainly can, and thereby their government, and they must be forced to pay for the rebuilding of East Timor.

Australia has its peacekeeping forces in East Timor, and we all welcome that. I know I speak for all people in central Victoria, and in fact for people all over Australia, in wishing those forces a successful mission and a safe return to Australia and their families. We owe an extreme debt of gratitude to the people of East Timor. We know how much assistance they were to us during the Second World War, and anything that this country and this parliament can do to help them must be done. They would have to be one of the most gentle races of people I have ever had anything to do with. Our hearts go out to all of them.

talk.start.para: —Like many members of this parliament, I have been negligent over the past 9½ years in that the problems of the people of East Timor have not been a top of the mind issue for me. Since my election in 1990 I have tended to concentrate on domestic issues such as economic growth, taxation reform, tariffs, welfare, and internal regional issues. These were the issues which were of primary concern to my electors and to organisations and lobby groups within my electorate. East Timor was never raised during these 9½ years as a top of the mind issue. It was not something we had to focus on as a matter of urgency.

speech.para: There was, however, one exception, a constituent of mine by the name of Mrs Olive Taylor, a member of the Noosa branch of the Liberal Party. Olive had a background in defence and her late husband was an international pilot with Qantas. Olive had a passionate concern for the people of East Timor and she never let an opportunity slip by without raising the plight of the East Timorese. Even in election campaigns when the topic of conversation was far removed from East Timor, Olive would go to public meetings and get to her feet and push the case for the problems of those people.

Like most Australians I was complacent, and like most Australians I left these problems to others whom I thought knew more than I did and who could handle foreign relations far more competently than I could. I accepted the assurances of the experts on both sides of this House over the past 25 years. East Timor has always been someone else's problem. So, Olive Taylor, all that time you were right. Your perceptions were far better based than many of your complacent colleagues, including me.

The eyes of the world finally focused on East Timor immediately prior to, during, and after the independence ballot. We sent unarmed Federal Police to supervise the ballot, we sent officers of the AEC, and Tim Fischer led a delegation of members of parliament to supervise the ballot. What happened after the results of the ballot were announced is now a sorrowful chapter in world history.

When the violence broke out Australians, including me, received a very loud and clear wake-up call. Australians saw atrocities never seen before in this region. We have seen over recent years atrocities, murder and the torture of people in Rwanda, Somalia and Kosovo, but that was far away, wasn't it. East Timor is part of our backyard. Nothing in my 9½ years has generated such a reaction from the people of my electorate as has the slaughter of the East Timorese. Families watching the nightly news saw men, women and children being butchered before our very eyes. We may never know the extent of the carnage.

The reaction of the Australian government was swift and right in the circumstances. It reflected quickly the mood and anger of the people. No member of a civilised society can stand back and condone the wholesale slaughter of his fellow men. I refuse to believe that the average person in Indonesia condones the wholesale slaughter by the integrationist militia, apparently aided and abetted by the Indonesian army.

No-one knows how this situation will evolve or how long it will take to resolve, but it does highlight a problem for this country. We have tended to put our heads in the sand and we have ignored the problem on both sides of the House. That problem is defence forces morale and conditions of service. Really, there have been decades of neglect and decades of erosion. Each one of us in our electorates have servicemen and we have ex-servicemen who have left the service and who wish they could have continued being servicemen, but the economics and the reality of pay and conditions are such that these people have no choice but to leave the defence forces.

I believe there are key points to note in regard to this issue of conditions of service. The Defence Efficiency Review conducted recently set defence personnel ranks at the lowest level since before the Vietnam War. Now we see we have a problem and we have to face that problem. How do we resolve it? Conditions of service erosion in recent years include: inflation has outstripped pay rises for at least the last three years and maybe more; rations and quarters charges for single defence personnel have increased; married quarters entitlement ratios have decreased to the disadvantage of servicemen; remote locality leave travel entitlements are affected by things like fringe benefits tax; constant changes to the defence superannuation scheme have increased the age entitlements that can be received. Resignations in the Army are far outstripping recruitment.

These are notes I have made resulting from quite a few years of dealing with defence personnel and their complaints to me as constituents. Complaints they make include that they are not happy with defence leadership. There is a perception that the ADF lacks leadership at the highest levels. They say that there is serious dissatisfaction with the Chief of Defence Force as well as other key army leaders who have sold out defence personnel for their own gain. There has been a series of senior leaders in Defence who were effectively sacked or passed over because they had the integrity to say `enough is enough'. They complained bitterly about cuts in the defence budget.

Another problem area which has to be addressed is isolation. Because of Australia's vast coastline, the Army particularly has seen an increasing trend of moving troops to isolated locations such as Darwin, Puckapunyal and others. Prime locations in urban areas are being sold with no concept of the long-term effects. As I say, these are issues that the men are raising with me.

The view on conscription is that it should be discouraged. Good recruiting and conditions of service will rectify this situation. A good soldier is one we can use for at least 10 years, not one year or two years. It would be better to have half the number of volunteer soldiers with higher morale than soldiers who do not want to be there. There would not be one professional army officer who would support conscription in this situation. The East Timor crisis, they believe, will in the short term lead to an increase in recruitment. This crisis has also helped to increase morale and revitalise the Army. Army personnel actually look forward to overseas operational service; this is what they are trained for.

In conclusion, it is time, at the turn of this century, to address what has happened to our defence forces and their readiness. I have the greatest of respect and sympathy for the men and women who have gone to East Timor to serve their country, and for those who will also go in the coming months. I feel for their families, the mums and dads, the wives and the kids and the loved ones. This nation owes them a great debt and I think we should start paying it now. Thank you.

para.inline: Sitting suspended from 6.31 p.m. to 8.00 p.m.

talk.start.para: —In referring to the United Nations Security Council resolution on East Timor, like other members speaking to this motion, I want to relate and state what I feel on this occasion. I believe the last time I spoke on something as tragic as this was before the House in January 1991. On that occasion, the Hawke Labor government had just made what was arguably its most difficult decision: to commit our Australian troops to the Persian Gulf as part of the United Nations force determined to liberate Kuwait from the occupying Iraqi army.

speech.para: Recently, as we all know, circumstances in East Timor have demanded that the Howard coalition government make an equally difficult and painful decision. Beginning on the weekend of 17-18 September and continuing in earnest throughout last week, Australia's service men and women once again entered a theatre of conflict with all the dangers and threats inherent in such a commitment.

Just as the coalition in opposition offered its full support to the Labor government in 1991, so too do we, the Australian Labor Party in opposition, offer our support to the Prime Minister and his government in making this difficult decision. We just wish the decision had come sooner. While the opposition's support for Australia's troops in the field and for the government's decision to send them to East Timor remains unqualified, we do have some very serious concerns about the way the government has managed our role in this whole affair. I would like to return to those concerns later in my speech.

Australia's forces in East Timor have embarked on an operation unique in our country's military and political history. For the first time, Australia leads a multinational force into the field. This is a challenge far beyond anything that Australian troops and service personnel have encountered since Vietnam and beyond. The objective of the multinational force is, I believe, no less forbidding—that is, the restoration and maintenance of law and order in East Timor and the facilitation of a peaceful, safe environment for its citizens that will allow them to move peacefully towards full self-determination. As a consequence of taking on this leading role, the numbers of Australian service personnel committed to the conflict are required at a level not seen since the conflict in Vietnam. Indeed, we are seeing a level of mobilisation of the Australian armed forces that we have not seen, I would venture to say, since World War II.

Any time our Australian men and women are placed in a dangerous or a threatening position as a result of their membership of the armed services it gives us all cause for concern—for them and for their families and loved ones. But somehow our concerns and our emotions this time are even stronger. As the Leader of the Opposition said while addressing those troops in Darwin on 20 September:
This is different.
He went on to say:
This is a new stage in the responsibility of the Australian people. This is a different page in Australian history being written here.

In talking with my constituents over the last few weeks, I know that, especially in recent days as Australia's role in this peacekeeping force has become clearer, they, too, recognise that a new chapter in Australia's history is being written with our involvement in East Timor.

With this greater level of responsibility come greater challenges, greater dangers, and Australian service men and women face the prospect of paying greater sacrifices for their service. We know they will not shirk taking on that extra responsibility. We also know they will not fail to take on any challenge and see it through successfully. We know they will not falter from paying any sacrifice to get the job done. For that, we all owe them a great debt of gratitude.

Without a doubt, the people of Australia are fully supportive of our men and women in uniform. The people of Australia are with them as they embark on this dangerous mission. Our thoughts are also with their families and their loved ones, especially their spouses, partners and children. We pray it will not be too long before they are again united, safe and on home soil. They are extremely well trained. They are competent and capable young men and women, they have trained for the moment when their country would call on them to put their training to good use—and now is that time.

It would have been better, however—certainly for the people of East Timor—had that time come earlier. We cannot discuss the situation in East Timor—the devastating violence and terror that have been witnessed there over the past weeks and the involvement of our Australian troops—without raising questions about the way in which the federal government has handled this matter.

One of the more obvious questions—and one yet to be adequately addressed by either the Prime Minister or the Minister for Foreign Affairs—is why a greater effort was not made to convince the Indonesian authorities to introduce a UN peacekeeping force into East Timor before the independent ballot took place. If, as we know, that it was only because of the influence of the United States that the UN and Australia were able to convince the Indonesians to receive an international peacekeeping force in East Timor, then surely logic dictates that, had we marshalled US influence prior to the independence ballot, then a multinational force could have been in East Timor much earlier. It is a question that remains to be answered.

If such a force had been in place, could we honestly say that the level of violence and upheaval that we have seen in East Timor would have taken place? It certainly would not have occurred on the same level that we have now seen. We knew—both from leaked documents and from the brazen statements made by senior members of the TNI—that the Indonesian army and its sponsored militias intended to embark on a reign of terror if the result of the ballot was a vote for independence. Australia's failure to get an international peacekeeping force into East Timor before the ballot—indeed, the Prime Minister's and foreign minister's grim refusal to even consider such a proposal—hangs over this government as the INTERFET force, having arrived in Dili, surveys the devastation and destruction.

Indeed, questions must also be raised over the Australian government's failure to work harder at convincing Indonesia to allow East Timor a period of greater autonomy before an independence ballot took place. This would, I believe, have created a much smoother transfer to self-determination. That is what the people wanted. The Prime Minister seemed to want that, too, at one stage. He raised the prospect of East Timor passing through a period of greater autonomy before reaching independence with President Habibie. But, once the President signalled his opposing view, that was the end of it for him—our Prime Minister—and the foreign minister. Indeed, the Prime Minister and foreign minister helped drive the independence ballot forward at a cracking pace, ignoring all the signs and the military intelligence that, to push ahead for a ballot—especially without an international peacekeeping force in place—would lead to the slaughter of hundreds, if not thousands, of innocent people and the complete devastation of East Timor. We have to turn only to our nightly news to see that this has happened.

Australia played a part in convincing the East Timorese that they could vote in safety and security and that there would be no retribution if they exercised their democratic rights. Because of our government's mismanagement of this situation, and because of the mismanagement of the UN, we have failed the East Timorese people—just as governments of all political persuasions have failed them in the past. We failed, but they have paid the consequences for our failure.

The foreign minister has repeatedly congratulated himself and the government on the speed in which they have rallied an international force together for East Timor, but, if the truth be told, we saw three weeks of desperate improvisation on behalf of this government. The foreign minister and the Prime Minister should not be allowed to claim any credit for themselves over their handling of the East Timor situation. Quite the contrary, rather than accept the accolades, the Prime Minister and the foreign minister have many serious questions to answer regarding the debacle into which East Timor has finally descended. Once and for all, they have been exposed, I believe, as amateurs in foreign affairs that we already knew them to be, but this time we have had and seen devastating consequences. You cannot rewrite history. I believe Prime Minister Howard has tried to do that, but the people of Australia have long memories and will not allow it.

I was most concerned to see on tonight's news our forces going through town after town and village after village and the scorched earth policy that has been implemented. On tonight's 7.30 Report, sadly, it was said that there was `destruction on a scale that no-one could ever have imagined'. I believe—and reports have shown this, even on tonight's news—that over 80 per cent of houses, buildings and infrastructure have been completely destroyed as the TNI make their way back to Indonesia.

As our people start coming in to aid, assist and help the East Timorese people, it is going to take more than six months; it is going to take more than 12 months. It will take many years to put that country back on its feet. The people are certainly entitled to help and assistance but, more importantly, they are entitled to explanations, as the people of Australia are entitled to explanations. One of the first major questions has to be why we did not move sooner and why we did not act more quickly. More importantly, when people say how quickly we did act, I say to those people that there are many people now buried over there who perhaps would have been alive today if we had acted sooner than others thought was a great triumph, and I really condemn the government for that. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —The present debate on this UN resolution on East Timor reminds us that in Australia we take for granted a freedom of political expression which does not occur in Indonesia and does not occur in East Timor. It was 24 years ago when Indonesia invaded East Timor; it has been there for that time. Now, I understand, only 1,500 of its troops are left there.

speech.para: Of course every Australian has been positively dismayed at the scenes that they have watched in the news on television. I have not had the opportunity tonight but I understand, having phoned home, that the pictures are still of people finding trashing of buildings and trashing of areas as the TNI pulls out. I understand that photographs have been found linking some members of the TNI with the militia. This has all been most unfortunate and most extraordinary. But, as the Prime Minister has said as recently as today in the parliament, governments of both political persuasions have made mistakes in their foreign policy in relation to East Timor and also to Indonesia.

I am reminded of just how important that vote for independence was: East Timorese being given, for the first time in their lives, the opportunity to vote and have some say in their future. I think there were very few people around who thought that this was all going to go smoothly. The fact that the ballot took place at all was nothing short of extraordinary. The opposition has chosen to attempt to score cheap political points on this but there is no way, as we have heard time and time again, that Indonesia would have allowed a peacekeeping force in to supervise that election. It was held with United Nations observers, including some of our own members of parliament. But what we have seen since, some people are saying, was predictable.

The Prime Minister, in speaking to this motion, said that there was no more serious decision that any government could take than to commit Australian military forces abroad. There was a great seriousness in the chamber as we all listened to what he had to say, but then I was quite genuinely dismayed to hear the Leader of the Opposition attempt to turn this into a political debate, because this was not a subject for one political party over the other. It was something for the Australian parliament and it was something for the Australian people. It was a very serious commitment to be committing young, well-trained men and women of the Australian armed forces to combat in another country—extremely serious. Yet even on that occasion we could not have a situation where the Leader of the Opposition would join in a bipartisan way with the Prime Minister of this country to discuss this motion.

I regret having to bring politics into this at all, because I think we are the most fortunate people, in the most fortunate country, in the world. But I remind those on the other side who wish to make this a political issue that it was the previous Prime Minister, Mr Keating, who signed the Timor Gap treaty with no parliamentary debate, no usual process. He was making foreign policy work in that area in what he considered was a relationship built on his special relationship with the leadership of Indonesia. And a previous Prime Minister, Mr Whitlam, while not endorsing Indonesia's invasion of East Timor 24 years ago, certainly understood it and publicly said so.

It is unfortunate that today, and during this week as we speak to this motion, these things have to be raised at all. I would like to think that Australian armed forces in East Timor could be sure in the knowledge that every member of the Australian public and the Australian government was behind them wishing them a safe and speedy return and that they were being prayed for every day. There would not be a mother in Australia who would not be concerned that her son might at some stage have to fight to serve his country. These are very serious times, and we do not know when they will finish. It has been very important that Australia act with the United Nations, that we act with the countries that are friendly in this region and that we be part of a multinational force.

Growing up after the Second World War, I remember discussions at that time that the United Nations was to be our great hope—the great hope for having nations around the world working together to ensure peace. The United Nations has taken part in 42 peacekeeping operations since 1948, and Australia has participated in 20 of them. They include operations in India and Pakistan from 1950 to 1985, a Federal Police presence in Cyprus from 1964 until the present, operations in Iran and Iraq from 1988 to 1990, in Cambodia from 1991 to 1993, in Croatia and Bosnia-Herzegovina from 1992 to the present, in Somalia from 1992 to 1995, in Rwanda from 1994 to 1995 and in Mozambique in 1994. All these efforts are reminders of what Australia has been doing as part of our United Nations obligations. But this is different. This is our troops in large numbers. This is Australia leading a force in our own part of the world.

The founders of the United Nations were determined that it would work to save succeeding generations from the ravages of war. Peacekeeping has perhaps been the most visible way in which the international community has tried to meet this objective, but there have been other ways, too. There has been increasing interest in the provision of electoral assistance, and Australia has been increasingly involved in this area—as we were in the ballot that took place on 30 August.

Like other members of this parliament, I have been influenced by what I have heard from my constituents. Working in my Adelaide office sometimes well past 8 o'clock at night, I know that people ring the number on instinct—probably not expecting it to be answered—because they have watched the news that night and have seen what has been occurring. It has always been beyond my comprehension how one human being could slice up, torture or put another to death. It is something I have not really been able to understand—unless one was protecting one's own family and one's own life. But that has not been the case. The East Timorese, like other oppressed peoples around the world, have suffered and are suffering.

But Australia is doing its best. To every man and woman in our armed forces who is there serving their country, doing what they are trained to do and representing all other Australians in East Timor, I wish a safe return. I trust that this matter will not be a long time in the settling, but I fear otherwise. I think there will be a high financial and personal cost to Australia being part of this peacekeeping force—or trying to install some kind of peace before it can be kept. I wish our troops well, I wish the East Timorese some peace in the future and, also in the future, I hope that, as we debate these issues, we will do so as a parliament and leave cheap political point scoring out of it.

talk.start.para: —All members of parliament on both sides wish our troops in East Timor well and a safe return home. While we may disagree in some ways with the government's method of getting there, no-one—either on my side of the parliament or on the government's side—is in any way being derogatory about the role of Australia's soldiers in Timor. I am sure that was not the import of what the member for Adelaide was saying about my colleague Mrs Crosio, who spoke earlier.

speech.para: Like everybody else in Australia, I have been deeply saddened by recent events in East Timor. It is impossible not to be moved by the tragic circumstances of the East Timorese with the graphic images and reports of violence and atrocities perpetrated upon them. The overwhelming majority of the East Timorese people, when given the opportunity on 30 August to choose their future, voted for independence. No-one could doubt their determination to be independent and their joyful reaction when they learned the result of the vote. About 80 per cent of those eligible to vote voted for independence and the people, at the end of it, were very happy. Unfortunately, their happiness was short-lived. A wave of violence swept over the island and it seemed little could be done to stop it.

The frustration of being unable to do anything to realistically stop the violence was felt by all Australians. With the United Nations resolution in place and the presence of the multinational force in East Timor, there is now a different set of feelings being experienced. For the first time, Australia is leading a multinational force and that puts an awful responsibility on us. Many of us will know someone who has a family member in the defence forces. Young men and women are being transported to the small island of East Timor not to defend their own country but to help stand up for a small group of people who want to be their own people and not part of a neighbour's empire.

There are a number of things that worry me about our involvement in East Timor. We are not a large country in world terms. We are larger than East Timor, of course, but not a really big player when it comes to world conflicts. Sure, we are willing to join in with other democratic nations to assist where we can, but we cannot do it all on our own. While I am aware that we are certainly not alone in East Timor, the government has accepted a huge responsibility. While I have confidence in our armed forces, and am sure that they will do their very best in the situation they find themselves in, I do not want Australia to be drained of the best resources and left with a depleted Defence Force in years to come. It also needs to be acknowledged that this is not going to be a quick and easy operation. It could go on for years. Even if the militia were quietened down, you would still need a strong presence there. You could never be sure that peace could be sustained.

When the issue of East Timor is discussed by politicians, the temptation to bring politics into it is almost overwhelming. Political point scoring is the order of the day for many. I do not want to do this. I want to look to the future and what is best for Australia as well as Timor. We need to keep our mind on the future and our place in the world. We need to think of the importance of independence for the Timorese and the importance of Australia's relations with our neighbours. We are not a large enough country to sustain a big commitment to East Timor indefinitely. We cannot afford to have our troops locked into an engagement in East Timor forever. I believe we need to have a realistic balance which is in the best interests of the East Timorese and the best interests of Australia.

There is probably a need to have some of the political rhetoric wound back. This morning on AM I heard a diplomat say that he believed that the last few weeks had destroyed 50 years of engagement between Australia and Indonesia. If that is true, I think that is a very sad thing. It is sad for both Australia and Indonesia and I hope that it is not true. Too much political rhetoric by both the newspapers and politicians can end up making a situation which is terrible even worse. Comments, for instance, made by commentators that compare what has happened in East Timor to the Holocaust and to Rwanda are just taking it too far. Let us be very clear about this: the Holocaust and Rwanda were state sponsored murder, sanctioned from the highest level of the state and were state policy.

No-one in their right mind can say that what has happened in East Timor is the policy of President Habibie and his government. There are disturbing reports that elements of the TNI have been involved, but no-one can say that President Habibie has had this as his government's policy. To compare what has happened in Timor to the Holocaust and to Rwanda says just that. Indeed, I think the reverse might be true: that President Habibie, if he can be criticised in this issue, can probably be criticised for moving too fast to allow self-determination and independence. It is not the policy of him or his government to kill the Timorese people.

Other government commentators have suggested that there should be conscription to fill up the Australian Defence Force. What a quaint 19th century Tory view that is—let's start a small war and conscript the unemployed to fight it for us! These are the sorts of rhetoric which I do not think do Australia or Indonesia or Timor any good. What has happened in Timor is most disgraceful. If only one person has been killed it is a tragedy for that person and for their family, and we Australians must provide help. But let us not demonise the Indonesian people in doing this because this is not a war that they have started. They are not the people who are to blame.

Some inquiry in the future might show us who are the people to blame. But it certainly is not the Indonesian people and I do not believe it is President Habibie and his government. Indeed, he will probably be the person who loses his job over this, so he will pay the price for the decisions that he has made.

It is really time for us to wind back a bit of the political rhetoric. And it is time for us to consider what we as Australians can do and what we should be encouraging our friends in Indonesia to do. We should not be getting into these bellicose arguments about how it is necessary for Australia to rearm, about how we should be improving the size of our Defence Force, because all that does is send a signal to our neighbour that we are not really interested in engagement and involvement with them but that we see them as the enemy. I think people in this parliament should make sure that we do not see that happening.

Having sounded those cautionary thoughts, I sincerely hope and pray that the situation in East Timor can be put right. Unlike most Australians, I have had the privilege to visit East Timor and I was struck by the relative unsophistication, quiet dignity and determination, and deeply felt Christian faith of the majority of its people. For many years now those people have suffered and have wanted to lead independent lives. That is what I think a lot of the people in Indonesia have wanted to do. What we have seen in the recent little while have been steps towards proper and open elections and democracy in Indonesia. That, for us, in our region and with our largest neighbour, is very important. I do not think we should see all those good things that have happened in Indonesia get washed away, in the minds of Australians, by what has happened in Timor.

As I said at the beginning, the people of Timor have been trodden on and have suffered the consequences of being a small community with a bigger neighbour, but they have remained true to themselves and their faith. We should remain true to our friendship with both the Timorese people and the Indonesian people. We should make it very clear, in the things we say and the things we do, that we have a vast distaste for what has happened in Timor and that if the Timorese people have chosen to be independent they have that right, as we and others have that right. But we should ensure that we also send a signal to our friends in Indonesia that our argument is not with them, that our argument is about what has happened in Timor. I think we should just take a step back and take a little bit of a deep breath to ensure that we stand up for the rights of the people of Timor and, in the same circumstances, ensure that we encourage the Indonesian people to continue the friendship that they have with us and to continue down the path of democracy that they have started to take. These are thoughts that we should consider at this time as well.

talk.start.para: —It was with a degree of hesitation that I put my name down to speak to this motion because I thought, `There isn't anything that I could add to this that hasn't already been said.' I am sure that many members in one way or another have reiterated what has gone before them. But then I realised that I do not come to Canberra just to say and do the things that I think are important; I am here to represent more than 80,000 people in the electorate of Bradfield. From their perspective, I have a responsibility to put at least some comments on the public record.

speech.para: As our troops sailed to East Timor, it was with a sense of great apprehension that their families bade them farewell. That the safety and lives of Australians have been put at risk to secure the peace, dignity and survival of others is not new to Australians. Although mateship did not make it into the preamble, I thought it was rather ironic that, almost a century after Federation, that endearing, often uniquely Australian characteristic was being demonstrated by young Australians abroad—in this case in our region. That is something that ought not be lost on us. It reminds us perhaps that the more things change, the more they remain the same. I also thought that, as devastating as the inhumanity of human beings is towards others, as devastating as the images of East Timor and what we read about it are, in other parts of the world things as bad as that—in some cases even worse—are happening every day, yet in many ways, Australians seem desensitised to what goes on.

But in this case, we have something happening on our doorstep, and for reasons that are obvious to anyone who observes the political process and human behaviour, we understandably have greater concern about that. Yet some of us have been frustrated in not having other significant nations throughout the world appearing to share our concern. With a sense of impotent rage, we have seen—certainly I have seen, along with all honourable members—and heard cruel evidence of man's inhumanity to man in East Timor. At the same time, the political machinations of the Indonesian army have made very little—if any—sense, as soldiers seemed unwilling or unable to prevent the brutality so evident to anyone who can see, hear and feel. As each day unfolds, as the peacekeeping forces go further into East Timor, it would seem that there may be some basis for accusations that the Indonesian military—or at least sections of it—if not participating in some of these violent acts, certainly may have stood by as they occurred.

Over the last month my office has been deluged—and I mean deluged—by people advocating everything from the immediate dispatch of warships to harsh economic reprisals and indefinite trade bans on Indonesia. While not all of us have kept our feet on the ground, we are indeed fortunate that our Prime Minister, the Hon. John Howard, has. Troops into East Timor without United Nations endorsement and Indonesian government consent would be tantamount to invasion. There is every reason to believe that had Australia pressed stridently for a UN peacekeeping force before the ballot was held, it is likely Dr Habibie would not have allowed the ballot to be conducted at all.

Australia is in no position to invade anyone, let alone a country with military resources at least 12 times greater than our own. In advocating a vote for independence and subsequently leading the peacekeeping force, Australia is not regarded by many Indonesians as their favourite neighbour. Indonesia, the largest Muslim country in the world with 211 million people, attributes blame for a disastrous situation to Australia, amongst others. Whatever the rights and wrongs of this, like our troops, Australia is headed for an uncertain future.

As the economic repercussions of this human tragedy face the discipline of capital markets, a number of issues are already emerging. Defence expenditure is likely to increase. Whatever the member for Watson has said, it has become obvious, even to the most left-leaning Australian, that Australia is going to need to invest more in its defence forces, not because we want to send a message to Indonesia and other countries in our region that we are arming ourselves, but rather because it may be said that Australia is not perhaps adequately equipped through its defence forces to provide its contribution to humanitarian and peacekeeping work as we are currently doing.

The peacekeeping role is indefinite and is likely to require vigilance of shipping and trade routes, amongst other things. Refugee intakes might need to be increased at a time when tension in the region militates against Australia's ambition to become one of its key economic players. Advocates of economic sanctions against Indonesia, particularly the IMF rescue package, ignore two critical facts. The first is that the people who would suffer most are already the poorest of the poor. Sixty million Indonesians have been sending their kids to bed hungry at night for almost two years, and some people want to make it worse it would seem.

The second fact relates to self-interest through which, with a degree of concern, I notice foreign policy seems to be conducted increasingly over the last few years. Financial instability means one thing, and that is political instability. To urge the withdrawal of financial assistance to a country that is only beginning to emerge from the worst currency and equity crisis in its history is to impose a slow and agonisingly painful revenge which will not easily be forgotten by our northerly neighbours.

Australia's measured response has been as decisive as circumstances would allow, and the UN Security Council, as we have been reminded by the Prime Minister, has made a significant decision in record time. In avoiding precipitate action it may be that a far worse long-term outcome of human and social condition dimensions has been avoided. We will never know.

One of the disappointing aspects of the debate about the motion, and I refer particularly to the Leader of the Opposition, is that there have been some attempts by people on both sides of politics to assign blame for foreign policy decisions in relation to East Timor over the last 20 years. It is very easy for any of us to look back in hindsight and say that the right or the wrong thing was not done, but I do not think it is going to serve the interests of anybody for us to blame any of our previous governments, whether they be Labor or coalition governments, which really thought that they were doing the best thing for both the East Timorese and for Australia at the time.

The other point that I would like to make is that Australia and Indonesia are evolving in their own respective ways. Australia is only just beginning to adjust to its place in this region, both economically and socially. Mr Keating as the Prime Minister pushed it in a particular direction, much to the consternation of many Australians. But so too are the Indonesians starting to feel the first stirrings of real democratic processes. I think it is going to be a tumultuous period. We do not know where this whole East Timorese situation is going to end up, but it is going to be difficult. I would like to think that in the long term Australia and Indonesia and our other Asian partners will develop a more enduring and substantive relationship than perhaps we might have been led to believe existed when Mr Keating was the Prime Minister.

I would also like to reinforce the comments made by the member for Watson criticising suggestions that we have conscription. I would like to fully endorse those remarks. I believe that it is nonsense to be suggesting that we go back to conscription, particularly in relation to this matter. And whilst I am a strong supporter of work for the dole, I do not particularly want to live in a country that has to fight for the dole.

Thank you for giving me the opportunity to speak. I strongly support the motion in the terms that have been described. Let us hope that Australian troops are home soon, as much for the sake of the East Timorese as for ourselves.

talk.start.para: —Last Tuesday the parliament unanimously passed a motion in relation to East Timor. Part of that motion was a formal recognition of the UN Security Council resolution 1264, which is the subject of tonight's debate in the Main Committee. There can be no greater decision of any government than to commit troops for overseas service. No matter what the circumstances, a debate by the federal parliament in this environment is of great moment. The fact that the motion of last week received unanimous support in both houses is a clear reflection of Australia's resolve to contribute now, in 1999, in the most positive way to help the East Timorese people attain their quest for independence.

speech.para: In my original notes, I have written that I do not wish in this debate to enter into discussion about whether the Howard government could have acted in a more decisive manner to minimise the bloodshed since the referendum on 30 August. On some occasions, having reviewed the debate and having now listened to the further debate, I am a bit ambivalent about whether I wish to enter into a further discussion. The issues have well and truly been canvassed, especially the clear evidence of the availability of intelligence reports and the statements of East Timorese leaders predicting that the retribution carried out by pro-integrationist forces would, in fact, occur.

Whilst it is important to acknowledge the availability of these assessments, I believe it is still important to acknowledge that these are not the first intelligence reports over the last 25 years that have been ignored by successive governments. When some of those on the other side choose to criticise the actions of Labor governments over the past 25 years—whether it be the Whitlam, the Hawke or the Keating government—there has been a fairly consistent attitude by the leadership of not only the Labor Party but also the coalition on this matter. That is not to say that there have not been brave souls, individual members, who stuck their necks out in putting views that went against the views of the leadership of their political parties. The issue of East Timor has always had a special place and, as individuals, from time to time we have tried to come to grips with the reasons for previous decisions.

The reaction of young people to the issue of East Timor has interested me. Soon after being elected to this place, I came to realise that many Australians who questioned what successive governments had done in East Timor were too young to realise what had actually happened. They had therefore made a judgment based on the evidence that they had gathered, and based on what they thought should have happened in contemporary times. This is an issue that has always been important within the Australian public. Therefore, the men and women of the Australian defence forces who are now deployed in Timor have the greatest support of the Australian public.

No matter how robust the debate has been on the motion moved in the House of Representatives or on the notation of this UN resolution, there is one clear fact: all members of this parliament give their greatest support to the ADF forces. They support those forces and hope that they are able to return safely as soon as possible.

I know that this is one occasion when I feel very confident that I can put not only a personal view but also a view on behalf of the people I represent here in this place—the electors of Scullin. They would wish me to convey to those people serving in East Timor—in the knowledge that those people serving will do so in the most professional manner possible—the hope that they return safely in the not too distant future. Regrettably, it would appear that that not too distant future may be a little way off. In talking about those serving in the ADF, we would also like to ensure that those serving as humanitarian workers in East Timor also feel the support we have for the work that they are doing in trying to help the East Timorese people back to the greatest degree of normality.

It is important that those who have committed crimes against humanity in East Timor should be brought to account by the world community. It is not trite to say that some of the footage and stories that have been beamed out of East Timor are of the most horrific crimes imaginable. It would not be appropriate to think that those who carried them out would be able to get away with what they have done.

Another thing that Australia should play a leading role in is the humanitarian effort. Whilst, on behalf of the community, the government is encouraged to provide a safe haven to some of the refugees from East Timor, we should also remember that those efforts should be carried out in the context of ensuring that those who wish to return to East Timor can do so with great safety and success.

Another point that we should remember is that there are many in the Indonesian community who are involved in a great struggle to further democratise Indonesia, and they are deserving of our praise and our support. When we make comments, in general these should not be seen as being against the whole of the Indonesian populace but as a recognition that there is a determination that out of this Indonesian democracy can also gather great strength.

In the quaint language of the UN, this particular resolution concludes by saying that the Security Council decides `to remain actively seized of the matter'. I am not too sure what that actually means. If it is a very positive notion, I hope that the UN, through the Security Council and the other agencies, is `actively seized' of the matter with great urgency and determination so that the East Timorese people may be freed from the situation in which they find themselves. People such as Xanana Gusmao, Jose Ramos Horta and Bishop Belo—the leading public figures who have continued the struggle and who are supported by the many thousands brave enough to participate in the referendum to overwhelmingly support independence—are deserving of our greatest support. That is the reason Australia is involved—not for any reasons of territorial gain, but to see that the right thing is done.
I have quoted James Henry Scullin before, but I never actually thought that it might be appropriate in the context of a foreign affairs matter. This quote appears on Scullin's memorial. It says:
Justice and humanity demand interference whenever the weak are being crushed by the strong.
