It is in that context that I wholeheartedly support Australia's involvement now in INTERFET and, if required, later in peacekeeping troops in East Timor.

talk.start.para: —I support the motion before the House, and the action that Australia has taken in East Timor. Our action follows an internationally monitored democratic ballot, an overwhelming vote in favour of independence despite intimidation and threats of reprisals, a reign of terror, and a unanimous decision by the United Nations Security Council. In doing so, I wish first to express my gratitude to the men and women of the Australian defence forces who are putting themselves at risk and accepting hardship in order to serve Australia, the United Nations, the people of East Timor, democracy and justice. It is an honourable task that they are carrying out.

speech.para: It is a great pleasure to be able to stand in this House in bipartisan company to support such an historic resolution. I am sure the Australian defence personnel involved in East Timor, and the wider Australian community, will also welcome the bipartisan approach taken by this parliament. It is with hope that we in Australia look to a resolution of the humanitarian and military crises within East Timor and the quick restoration of good relations with Indonesia bilaterally and in the context of the international community and the region's neighbours.

East Timor has been for too long a running sore in South-East Asia. Although it is painful for all involved to have to dress the wound now, we look with hope to its rapid healing and to the time when we can all get on with helping each other to a better future without the threat of violence and the intimidation in East Timor. The history of the region since the Second World War has confirmed to all in South-East Asia that peacefulness and good relations within the countries of that region, and within the region itself, are the highway to economic prosperity for Australians, Indonesians and everyone else.

We keep extended our hand of friendship not only to the East Timorese but to all the people of the Republic of Indonesia. I give thanks to the Indonesian military leadership who, in the best spirit of international community cooperation, have facilitated the safe arrival of the international force in Dili. With respect and a warm heart, I sincerely ask the distinguished members of the Indonesian parliament and the Indonesian people to support their President's call for them to accept East Timor's vote for independence, as it is in their and all their neighbours' self-interest to do so. All in our region must look to the future, seeking reconciliation and mutual cooperation.

The dispatch of the Australian troops to East Timor on Monday, 20 September 1999 saw an interesting confluence of time and destiny. In a few weeks time there will be the centenary of the Australian colonial expeditionary force that was sent to South Africa following the outbreak of war between Britain and the two Dutch South African republics on 11 October 1899. After the Federation of the Commonwealth of Australia on 1 January 1901, there began the unification of these units—consisting largely of mounted rifles—in action in South Africa, which led to the whole force being designated for the first time as an Australian force.

There is another dimension to the dispatch of the Australian troops this week that is of notable distinction. The arrival of the troops was preceded not by an air bombardment of high explosive bombs, but by an airdrop of food and other emergency supplies to a displaced, starving and terrorised population. I ask those who are critical of Australia's involvement to note this. This follows decades of development and periodic emergency assistance worth billions of dollars to our neighbours in the near region.

If anyone in Indonesia wonders why Australia has taken the lead in coming to the aid of the East Timorese people, it is quite transparent. There is nothing sinister about it. It is a natural extension of the goodwill policies, largely in the form of grant aid, that Australia has been following in Asia for almost half a century, beginning with the Colombo Plan. As I speak, it is not bombs that are exploding on the Indonesian archipelago, but emergency food parcels fluttering to the ground, and you cannot get more benign than that.

Since the Federation of Australia in 1901, Australia's armed forces have come to know full well the seriousness of armed conflict. They have tasted the fruit of victory and have suffered the consequences of battles lost. Indeed, not only have many Australians on active war service lost their lives in the region but many have suffered terribly as captives. Australians understand what it means to be unarmed, unprotected and at the mercy of brutal and armed adversaries. This is another reason why Australia has given a high priority to the elimination of suffering in East Timor. We carry a heightened awareness of events in this part of the world, partly brought about by the shedding of Australian blood.

The loved ones of the Australian military personnel who today are left behind in Australia are experiencing the daily anxiety of hanging on to every word of every news bulletin and reading every newspaper report they can find. I have more than a few of those loved ones in my electorate. There are a number of military installations there, including one of Australia's largest military installations, the Holsworthy defence area.

For this reason, and for the sake of those who are personally involved in events in East Timor, I want to make something quite clear. It is this: despite what others have said in this House during this debate, the crisis that has occurred in East Timor is not due to any failure in Australian policy but to a failure in Indonesian policy. Australians have no cause to feel guilt or blame for what has happened and nor should this government. Nor should we be the scapegoat for the failures and misdemeanours of others or for the passing political advantage of others.

I want to say to the families of our troops that, whatever happens, your loved ones are in East Timor for the best possible reasons. They are there following the best possible efforts of the government and the international community to bring about a peaceful and just resolution of the slaughter and mayhem that has occurred in East Timor since Indonesia agreed to a United Nations ballot earlier this year. The government has ensured that the rules of engagement allow them to adequately protect themselves and the lives of others. As well as the best wishes of the Australian people, Australian defence personnel deployed in East Timor will receive tax free salaries and other benefits, including a set of tax free allowances totalling $125 a day. As well as receiving additional leave entitlements and loan subsidies, they are covered by the Commonwealth veterans' entitlement and the military compensation scheme should they be harmed. They will also become entitled to service pensions.

The Prime Minister has cautioned Australians about the dangers of this humanitarian mission to establish the rule of law and order. I have no doubt that Australians will stand up and bear any unpleasant consequences of the danger because we are united in our objectives in East Timor, as set out in the resolution before the House, and because it is a just cause, without any shadow of a doubt.

On behalf of many Australians, I give thanks to God for the democratic institutions of our nation which we too often take for granted. I give thanks to God for the men and women who place themselves in danger in order to protect others, whether it is to be police or emergency services personnel here in Australia or defence personnel undertaking hazardous assignments overseas. We pray for the peaceful and just resolution of the conflict in East Timor. We pray for the safe return to their homes and loved ones of those who have been sent forth from Australia and from other countries to make up the international force in East Timor. We thank God that help has arrived for the displaced, sick and dispossessed. We pray for his blessing upon all in the region. For all our Australian troops, we pray that he will bring them all safely home.

talk.start.para: —I would like to add to the comments of many members in the House on this motion on the UN resolution on East Timor. I commence by saying that I do not intend to canvass again many of the views that have already been put forward by members. The views about our involvement, as expressed in the contribution of my leader, Mr Beazley, at the commencement of this debate, sum up my views about the political issues surrounding our involvement.

speech.para: As one of the members of this place who was fairly heavily involved during the mid and late 1980s in the task of assisting Vietnam veterans achieve some proper recognition, I want all those serving to know that military involvement weighs heavily on the national psyche. There is not a person in this place who does not take very seriously and heavily the weight of decisions such as this to become involved. As every other member has expressed wishes of electorates, I also express the best wishes of every constituent in my electorate of Burke for the safety and wellbeing of the members of the defence forces now serving in East Timor and those who will follow on as well.

In the few minutes remaining for my contribution, I would like to canvass some ideas I have about where all this really ought to go a little further down the road. I believe that the Australian government has no option but to be planning now for a long-term involvement not only in the securing of peace but in the long-term rehabilitation of what has become a destitute, ravaged nation of people. We must make a long-term commitment to securing peace and security for these people. I believe that we now need to begin planning and perhaps building a coalition of helpers, of volunteers for when we are in a position to guarantee their safety and to say to the aid agencies that it is not just a case of securing peace for East Timorese people, not just of helping people return to their homeland, not just a matter of securing emergency accommodation and emergency food supplies for these people, but that in fact Australia has a much greater and longer-term obligation than that.

I believe that, for better or for worse, we have been a significant player in bringing on this vote for independence, in bringing on what has taken place, and I believe there is a national will to help in the long-term rebuilding of East Timor. I have not experienced that national will in such a broad range across the community in relation to anything else that we have been involved in in my time as a member of parliament. The will towards helping here is across all age groups and for a whole lot of different reasons, so I think there will be the opportunity for Australians to be more than willing about this.

The picture that I am trying to create is that the Australian government, with the support of the opposition, should be planning not only a long-term presence to secure safety and peace but that those transport links, the accommodation links, the supply links should be kept open. We should now be starting to build a volunteer force of people who are prepared to go to East Timor—be it for a month, two months, three months or a longer term—to actually take part in replacing the infrastructure and in helping people rebuild their homes; even going and looking at the 1974 manifesto of Fretilin.

Fretilin's manifesto in 1974 talked about building a nation. At that time, in the broad policy guidelines, there were items such as building a justice system, building a system of civil administration, building schools, running an education system and taking part in the world as a fully developed nation. Nowhere in that 1974 manifesto of Fretilin did they envisage doing it from rubble and ashes. The fact is that East Timor starts from a worse position than it was ever in in 1974 and a worse position than anyone ever envisaged. In my view, that means that Australians have a key role to play.

I cannot help but reflect on the many thousands of Australians who are in the huge group of 50-year-old people who have been displaced from the work force or told they can take their lump sum and go in their four-wheel drives and caravans and wander around Australia for the next 20 years. Do we seriously think that that is what these people want to do for the rest of their lives? Of course it is not. I think anyone half smart could now start reaching into groups of people like that who have enormous skills and who are grossly underutilised in Australia. It might be one in 100 of them, it might be one in 1,000, but I reckon it would be closer to one in 10 of them who would say, `Yes, if you could transport me there, if you could provide me with food while I am there, if you can guarantee my security, I'll go up and help them build a school, I'll help teach those kids, I'll help set up a local government structure, I'll help build a trade union,' or whatever it might be.

If we were to begin planning and talking about such a notion, I believe you would be amazed at the response you would get from Australians who would be willing to go and provide their presence, providing we can guarantee their security, providing we can transport them there, and providing we can accommodate them while they are carrying out that task. Such a proposal sent my mind back to the airline pilots strike of the late 1980s when there was a situation where the military did transport many of us around, not just VIPs and the rest. They went into action keeping the tourist industry alive during that horrific six months, particularly in North Queensland and in Tasmania. They kept the tourist industry alive by putting resources to work, proving the capability that is actually there.

I know this is all very optimistic. I have made preliminary assumptions in bringing a proposal like this forward. I have assumed that we will be able to secure peace. I have assumed that under a lot of pressure the government will reinvent the reserves and we will have an ongoing presence. I have assumed that as part of the UN force we can set in place the preconditions to do this. Having put those preconditions in place, I want us to start thinking now where we will take it from, not start thinking then.

I reiterate the thoughts I had at the outset, and that so many other members have conveyed in this debate, about our support for our personnel. I also place on notice now my belief that we need to begin thinking optimistically about how we can pull this nation together to actually make that longer term contribution.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the motion that this House:

speech.para: (1) notes the overwhelming choice for independence exercised by the East Timorese people on 30 August;

(2) welcomes United Nations Security Council Resolution 1264 authorising a multinational force to restore peace and security in East Timor, protect the United Nations' mission in East Timor and facilitate humanitarian assistance;
(3) endorses Australia's agreement to the United Nation's Secretary-General's request that Australia contribute to and lead the multinational force;
(4) expresses its full support for the Australians serving with the multinational force and its full confidence in them; and
(5) looks forward to their safe return home.

I support this resolution, particularly as a former serving member of the Women's Royal Australian Navy within the Australian Defence Force, and I am pleased that the opposition also supports it. It is a great honour to have served in the Australian Defence Force and now serve the Australian people as a federal member of parliament for the seat of Makin.

However, it is with some surprise and concern that I note the Australian media so far has not given credit for the fact that the Prime Minister has displayed some of the greatest statesmanship of all our prime ministers this century. The following ministers should be given credit for their endeavours to secure a peacekeeping force under the auspices of the United Nations: the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Alexander Downer; the Minister for Defence, John Moore; the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, Bruce Scott; and the Prime Minister.

Many countries are participating from within and from outside our immediate region. I understand that so far we have commitments from Brazil, Canada, France, Ireland, Italy, New Zealand, Norway, the Philippines, Portugal, Singapore, Malaysia, Thailand, the United States and the United Kingdom. I am delighted that all of these countries have made such a commitment, due largely to the efforts of our Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs.

However, on a sad note I am disappointed at the opportunism displayed by some members of the Labor Party on this issue. It can only be detrimental to the morale of our soldiers and all of the peacekeeping forces currently in East Timor. In fact, I am ashamed and appalled at the way the opposition is behaving in this matter. As the Prime Minister said in question time today, it is time to look forward—to work and concentrate on the present—to our continuing success in Operation Stabilise. It is at this point that congratulations of all of the Australian people should go not only to the Prime Minister, the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the Minister for Defence, the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence but also to our soldiers and the tremendous professional work that they are carrying out in East Timor.

I am heartened by the knowledge that all of the peacekeepers, but in particular our own Australian soldiers, are highly trained professional, committed and dedicated men and women. I salute all of them and their courage and would like them to know that this is not only my own personal point of view but my view as a federal member of parliament representing many Australians who are also justifiably proud of our peacekeepers. I also salute and commend the courage of their families and loved ones back home. I am heartened by the fact that our ministers and their support staff are doing everything in their power to support the families and loved ones of our men and women serving overseas.

Again, I would like to point out that it is simply irresponsible for the Labor Party to behave in the manner that it has. It was simply irresponsible for some people to suggest that the government should have somehow pushed harder than it did for Indonesia to accept a United Nations peacekeeping presence before the independence ballot.

It is on the record that our Prime Minister raised this very issue with President Habibie of Indonesia before the ballot, but that the Indonesian government was, at that stage, resolutely opposed to the idea. By suggesting that Australia should have pressed this case further than we did, in the face of clear Indonesian opposition, the Labor Party is suggesting that we should have thrown away our entire relationship with Indonesia at that point. Not only that, but we could possibly have jeopardised the prospect of there being any independence vote for East Timor at all. Instead, we did the only sensible thing under the circumstances: we prepared our own forces for what might—but still we hoped would not—happen.

Imagine Labor's alternative policy, that Australia humiliate the Indonesian government in international forums—and send our troops to be slaughtered. Even if the ballot had still gone ahead, under these circumstances Labor's policy would have guaranteed the unnecessary shedding of Australian blood in East Timor. Not only the militia but very likely the Indonesian military and the government would have been deeply antagonistic to our presence in East Timor under those circumstances.

As it is the INTERFET commander, Major General Peter Cosgrove, has reported that he has received cooperation from Indonesian military authorities. It is important to note here that our Prime Minister has praised President Habibie for realising the need for peacekeeping forces to enter East Timor under these difficult and tragic circumstances. No mistake should be made on this point. However dangerous our position in East Timor—and it is dangerous—it would have been made immeasurably more so had we acted in the way that the Labor Party is advocating.

The approach of this government to the East Timor question has been by far the most principled of any government since East Timor was integrated into Indonesia nearly a quarter of a century ago. This government has faced the issue squarely and acted at all times to find peaceful and diplomatically sustainable solutions to the East Timor question. In particular, I would like to commend Prime Minister John Howard and Foreign Minister Alexander Downer for their tireless efforts in the face of confused and contradictory criticisms from the opposition and some foreign policy commentators. I would also like to take this opportunity to send my personal message of thanks and good wishes to Australian personnel currently serving in East Timor as well as all of the United Nations peacekeeping forces. With those brave people go all of our thoughts and prayers for a safe and successful mission.

We are not in East Timor because it is the safe thing to do or the politically expedient or the popular thing to do. We are there because it is the right thing to do for the East Timorese. I applaud the conviction of our Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs, the courage of our defence forces and the tremendous generosity and goodwill of the Australian people.

I would like to echo our Prime Minister's comments, as I am sure many Australians do, that we pray for the speedy and safe return of all our Australian soldiers and that security and peace can be restored in East Timor for the good of the East Timorese, Indonesia and the security of our region in general. I hope that Australia can look forward to rebuilding its relationship with Indonesia.

talk.start.para: —At such moments in our history, we all must bear witness to the truth as we know it. This afternoon I listened to the members for Cook and Fairfax and their sincere comments about the failure all of us have exhibited in giving this issue the due weight it deserved over the last 25 years. For myself, I also say mea culpa.

speech.para: Many of us were gulled, I believe, by the positive democratic developments that took place in Indonesia during the last year. We believed that the referendum in East Timor could take place with a quasi democratic regime led by President Habibie. Supporters and, indeed, critics of the Howard-Downer-Habibie plan for the democratic referendum in East Timor underestimated the sheer bastardry of elements in the Indonesian ancien regime. We underestimated the evil of some elements in the Indonesian military such as General Zacky Anwar, whose legacy is burning churches and the uprooting of an entire people.

One person, in my view, however, stands out from the prevailing wisdom, and in my capacity as a member of the Labor Party's foreign affairs caucus committee I have had the honour to support him: the honourable member for Kingsford-Smith. His siren calls went unheeded, and hundreds of thousands of people have paid the price. Yes, it is true that all previous Australian governments bear historic guilt in this debate. It is true, however, that there is not a total historical discontinuity between past Indonesian-Australian relations and the cold peace that unfortunately exists between our two countries now. As the past foreign minister the Hon. Gareth Evans said:
. . . before the economic crisis of 1997—
in Indonesia—

and its political aftermath changed everything, we all had to live with the fact that there seemed no realistic chance of Indonesia ever actually agreeing to a fully-fledged act of self-determination in which independence was an option.
He went on to say:

. . . after 1997 the impossible suddenly seemed possible. It had nothing to do with the change of government in Canberra. Rather, the economic crisis or Indonesia coming under international pressure as never before, and desperate to garner international support. That and Suharto's downfall opened up brand new options for the resolution of the East Timor situation. John Howard correctly called one of them when he wrote to President Habibie in December 1998, urging Indonesia to grant East Timor significant autonomy immediately and to hold out the possibility of a full self-determination ballot at an unspecified later time. The trouble was that Habibie's response—inspired more by pique than high principle, and insufficiently canvassed with his military—went a quantum leap further than Howard has proposed, by throwing open the prospect of independence if autonomy was refused.

Unlike the previous speaker, I think that honest people can disagree about this issue. While all of us undoubtedly support the role of Australian troops in East Timor—indeed, some of us on this side of politics would be willing enough to be generous to the foreign minister and to the Prime Minister and say that the deployment did take place remarkably quickly—people on this side of politics do not believe there was an either/or option prior to the referendum taking place.

It may indeed be true that the referendum would have taken place only if the Indonesians were not forced to have a peacekeeping force there while the referendum was actually on. However, there are a great many other things that the Australian government might have done. The shadow foreign minister repeatedly pointed them out in question time in the previous months, and I remember them. I have been there since 3 October, and two events stand out in my mind in particular. They are the meeting where the head of the Australian foreign service met the US Assistant Secretary of State, Mr Stanley Roth, in January and, when asked about a contingency plan, Australia said, `We are not interested'; and later when one of our military officials was asked by a US Marine general about a similar contingency plan.

I believe that the telephone call made by the US Joint Chiefs of Staff to General Wiranto some days after the sacking and pillaging of Dili shows that other things could have been done. As the Leader of the Opposition and the shadow foreign minister have said, we should have been on the phone to the Americans making sure that the situation in Dili was tied down and that, if our influence could not be used, that the considerable influence of the US government was deployed with the Indonesians.

When General Shelton rang Wiranto—and, unlike our Minister for Defence, he was able to get through on the telephone—he immediately agreed, and Indonesia agreed soon after, to a peacekeeping force being deployed in Timor. If such pressure had been put on the Americans immediately prior to the referendum, the situation in East Timor might have remained relatively calm, as it did on referendum day. On referendum day, the Indonesian TNI showed that they could keep control in Indonesia, where 78 per cent of people voted for independence. I believe that, if Australia had fulfilled its responsibility of keeping the Americans focused on this part of the world immediately prior to the referendum, we could have concentrated the minds of General Wiranto, General Anwar and the various other people whose evil deeds we know about now.

During question time today, the Prime Minister distanced himself from the report in last week's Bulletin that he had announced a new strategic imperative for Australia—the Howard doctrine. Whether the Prime Minister used the actual words or not, what he argued for was as follows:
It is the more muscular Australia prepared to fulfil the role of regional deputy to the global US policeman . . . Howard embraces the "deputy" concept . . .
Australia . . . will draw strength from its distinctive characteristics of a Western civilisation in Asia; an Australia not seeking to fashion itself like the rest of Asia . . .

It is very disappointing for those of us who, like the Prime Minister, would like to look forward on this Timor issue, that such a fundamental commitment of our country's position seems to have been made on the run—not in a considered speech, not after extensive consultation with military and foreign policy advisers, but, with apologies to Mr Brenchley, in a throwaway interview in a weekly magazine. Doctrines can be extremely significant things. President James Monroe, the then President of the United States, told Congress in 1823;

We owe it, therefore, to candour and to the amicable relations between the United States and those powers (referring to European Powers) to declare that we should consider any attempt on their part to extend their system to any portion of this hemisphere as dangerous to our peace and safety . . .

He clearly did not have the same eye for history as our current Prime Minister. It was some time before historians and commentators came to refer to this enunciation as the `Monroe Doctrine'. The word `doctrine' was also their addendum.

Earlier this afternoon, we heard comments from the members for Leichhardt and Grey that some of the reactions to the Prime Minister were sensationalist and left-wing journalism, et cetera. A person whom I have never known as a left-wing journalist, Mr Greg Sheridan, a foreign editor of the Australian, had this to say about the so-called Howard doctrine:

Gaze out today on the rubble of what was once Australian foreign policy and weep. As Canberra races to find an ark of 1950s antiquity in which to carry its back-to-the-future Howard doctrine, the region has reacted with extreme hostility.
The Howard doctrine has instead overwhelmingly underlined every cliche and stereotype of white arrogance and neo-colonialism.
This is a dangerous moment for Australia. The understandable pride at our magnificent servicemen and women is in danger of spilling over into ugly and destructive jingoism.
And he concluded:
What is needed now is a steady, calm hand on the tiller, an emphasis on continuing friendship and engagement.
Instead we've had wild talk of fundamental change in Canberra's approach to the region, involving especially a new emphasis on military power.
And there is no sense at all that this has been thought through or the necessary policy figures consulted. This is a mess, built on failure. God knows where it is leading.
As for left-wingers and sensationalists, could I also quote David MacGibbon, a former Liberal senator and Chairman of the Joint Parliamentary Foreign Affairs Committee.

talk.start.para: —He's pretty left wing.
—Yes, he is a real red-ragger. He said:

speech.para: The real danger we face in all this is being seen as a post-colonial relic, isolated from Asia in a corner of the Pacific. It's very easy to run the campaign against Australia that we are isolated in Asia and we've spent 50 years trying to put a different perspective.

The tragedy of this foreign policy is not its implementation in Timor on the ground at the moment. The military forces are doing a fine job, a job that is supported by all of the Australian people. We have a great responsibility to see that at a future time they are replaced. The 7th Task Force, particularly, in Brisbane will have to be upgraded very rapidly, and certainly Australian military expenditures will need to be focused on providing more foot soldiers so those very professional service people can be transited out.

Honest people can disagree about what this government did in the past, prior to the referendum. Honest people can argue, as I believe the opposition does, that a different pressure could have been put on the Indonesian authorities and a different result would have been had in Timor.

talk.start.para: —Mr Deputy Speaker, do you have any objection if I make my remarks sitting down?
—No, that is fine. It may set a precedent that may well be continued.

—I can see little point in standing in a room where we are all so absolutely visible. In addressing the motion on the UN resolution on East Timor, and having watched the television records of what is happening in East Timor at the moment, I would like to commend the Australian forces on the impression that they have given, which is of a highly disciplined, very effective force. I, as one Australian, have been very proud to see the way that they have behaved: with dignity and yet at the same time with firmness. Certainly my congratulations go to Major General Cosgrove for the way that he has acted in an extremely difficult situation.

speech.para: Having said that, I would like to spend the rest of my time in comments on various issues. The first is East Timor itself, and Australia's obligation to East Timor. I read in the Australian several days ago a comment by Paul Kelly discussing the various myths, as he saw them. One of the myths that he named was Australia's `obligation' to East Timor. His point of view was that we had no obligation to East Timor and the feeling that post World War II we should have done something more for East Timor was neither practical nor even reasonable. I would disagree with Mr Kelly on that point.

My father was one of those servicemen during the Second World War who fought in the islands and near East Timor. They were very much aware at the time of how much their lives and safety depended on the East Timorese. They had an understanding with the East Timorese that the kindness, the putting aside of their own safety, the putting themselves at risk by the East Timorese for Australians would always be remembered by Australia. But after the events of 1975 there was a feeling that Australia had not remembered what had happened during the Second World War. I believe that within the country there was a feeling of, perhaps, shame that we had not done more to protest at what had happened to East Timor.

This is not to say that we could have changed the events of history. I doubt that we could have. But there was a complicity in our attitude to what had happened in East Timor which I think has caused many older Australians and, from them, their children and grandchildren to feel a sense of shame. That now has passed and I think there is a feeling in Australia that we have done the right thing: even by putting Australian lives at risk we are standing for principles that we believe in in East Timor. We are opposed to butchery, and we will step in where we can to prevent it from happening and to protect innocent women and children.

I have heard people say, `We will regret this decision because popular opinion will go against it when we see bodies coming home in bags.' Those people are treading on very dangerous ground. If it should happen that Australian lives are lost in Timor, the worst thing that we could do to the survivors and the relatives of those people who died, who gave their lives, would be to say that their involvement should not have happened, that we should not have been there. All that we should say is that they died for a good cause, and we need to say that if it happens, not to start at this stage saying, `Well, we weren't going to achieve anything anyway. It is not a good pragmatic decision because we may lose Australian lives.'

There is pride that we have taken the right decision. The feeling of the population is that we have finally stood up for the liberal democratic values that we are supposed to hold in this country and there is a time to say that these values are more important than pragmatism.

Having said that, I would like to briefly touch on the role that the opposition has played in this debate. It is not one that I suspect covers the opposition with any great honour. They have had two arguments against the course of events. The first is that Australia should have sent in peacekeeping forces earlier. The second is that there should have been a coalition of peacekeepers before the ballot. Both of these points are so far from what was possible as to be ludicrous. To go back, we did not know what the vote on East Timor was going to be, and neither did Indonesia. I defy anybody to say that they were not surprised when they saw the extent of that yes vote, especially after the intimidation that had gone on in East Timor.

We did not know how the referendum was going to pan out, neither did Indonesia. Although we were afraid of what the militia might do, we could not prejudge the issue. To do so would have brought the severest condemnation not only from Indonesia but from all of our other South-East Asian neighbours. We could not say, `This is going to happen: let's rush in.'

Let us also look at the practicality. When we finally did go in as a peacekeeping force, it was with the agreement of Indonesia. We could not have gone in without that agreement, without declaring war on Indonesia, which was obviously patently ridiculous. It also followed a resolution of the United Nations. That resolution only followed an invitation by Indonesia. We had to have that invitation.

If the opposition thinks there was any real likelihood of Indonesia offering that invitation beforehand, they should have a look at what was needed to eventually get that invitation. It was the television sets around the world displaying the violence that was erupting in East Timor and the actions of the militia. On top of that, it required pressure from the United States and also from neighbouring countries and the International Monetary Fund. That pressure had to be there at the end in face of what was happening to get Indonesia to make that offer. But the opposition has sought to find party political advantage in this situation which, for the welfare of the whole of this continent, is a very dangerous thing to do.

Indonesia is upset about what happened in East Timor. It had spent a lot of money and time in trying to secure the province and it was slapped in the face with a 78 per cent vote against it. Following that, it has the condemnation of Australia. It does not need, therefore, any encouragement from Australian politicians for Indonesia to start badmouthing Australia. How does the opposition think that the leadership of other South-East Asian countries, such as Thailand, react when they see not only Indonesia criticising Australia but also Australia's own politicians?

They do not see it in the way that we see it, as party political point scoring, but they see it as dissension within Australia about the role we are playing in East Timor. In doing so, the Leader of the Opposition has much to answer for. It may be that it was in response to the stinging criticism of his ex-colleague that he had an un-Churchillian streak of timidity. This was not the time to show that he was not timid. It was a time to unify all Australians to stand behind Australia's effort in East Timor and to look to the future of Australia and East Timor.

Finally, may I say that it is in East Timor's interest that Australia have good relations with Indonesia because we do not need Indonesia taking out anger at Australia on East Timor. Despite the posturing of the opposition, it is not Australia who will be the be-all and end-all of what happens in East Timor. It is very much up to the Indonesian military whether they continue to support the militia in East Timor or not. If we look to the future, we have to try to stabilise the relationship with Indonesia, not just for the sake of the relationship itself but for the interests of all East Timorese and the future of a stable and secure East Timor.

talk.start.para: —Before I go through the body of the statement that I want to make, I do want to make one reference to the previous speaker, the member for Hindmarsh. Taking on board her acceptance of the commitment and obligation that we owe East Timor, all I wanted to say was that the UN promised that they would be there before, during and after the ballot. They gave a commitment to the East Timorese people that the Timorese believed.

speech.para: Let me say that I do endorse the motion currently before the House and, in doing so, I certainly echo the sentiments of my electorate. The support that the Australian community has for the people of East Timor is enormous. By supporting this motion, we have sent a clear message to the Australian and the international communities that the Australian parliament is serious about the protection of life and liberty in East Timor. The only solution is to stop the violence so that the East Timorese people can live in safety. We must also commit ourselves to the rebuilding of East Timor when peace is a reality. These people have lost not only their security but their infrastructure.

Over the last few weeks we have all seen the destruction of towns and the murder of thousands. There are reports by the few remaining journalists and those gradually returning that the atrocities have been incredibly disturbing. The annexation of East Timor by Indonesia has had a devastating effect on the East Timorese people. Estimates have been made that between 100,000 and 200,000 people have lost their lives as a direct result of the conflict in East Timor over the last 24 years. Over the last few weeks we have all seen the destruction of Dili and the murder of thousands. The television coverage of the situation in East Timor has been disturbing but it has brought home to the Australian community the importance of Australian participation in moves to assist the East Timorese. I would like to take this opportunity to applaud the courage of the Australian troops now in East Timor, or as the Leader of the Opposition called them, our `young Australian warriors'. I have, like other members, received a huge amount of correspondence regarding the situation in East Timor. One email I received last week struck a particular chord with me and I would like to share some of the comments of the writer with members today. She said:

I am a soldier's wife. My husband is very likely to be deployed overseas if the Liberals ever get their finger out. It needs to be done, they need our help. I have four children and I just think of all the poor kids over there who need a digger's hug and safety they can provide. If I didn't think this was necessary I would not be writing this. I don't normally want my husband to put himself in danger but, for God's sake, it needs to be done.
This email was signed `Just a diggers wife'.

The friends and family of these defence personnel are justifiably concerned about the safety of these Australians, but I believe they appreciate the importance of this commitment to peace. When entering a career in the military, people are making a commitment to the security of Australia, and at a time such as this they have also made a commitment to the security and safety of our region. While these defence personnel accept the risk associated with their career choices, any moves into areas of conflict necessarily increase the potential for harm. I wish, therefore, to thank those people for their commitment to Australia and wish each of them a safe return to family and friends.

I think we need to ask ourselves in exactly what context we are sending our young warriors to the killing fields of East Timor. I am concerned that the situation in East Timor has degenerated without the Australian government having adequately prepared for these highly predictable circumstances. According to the shadow minister for foreign affairs, the member for Kingsford-Smith, there are two main reasons for the situation in East Timor reaching this crisis point. Firstly, there was the decision to allow the independence process to move quickly and disregard the intelligence outlining the potential for bloodshed should the TNI remain in force with the so-called militia forces which, media reports indicate, is operating with, at the very least, the tacit support of the Indonesian military. Secondly, there was the delay in involving the United States.

In November 1998 Xanana Gusmao suggested a timetable for the territory to gain independence from Indonesia. The essence of it was that 18 months should be spent solving problems relating to security, which included the disarming of paramilitary groups followed by a transition process lasting at least three years during which there would be a political education program and the establishment of an East Timorese police force as part of a possible deployment of peacekeeping forces.

Xanana Gusmao, with Noble laureates Jose Ramos Horta and Bishop Belo, suggested that it might be necessary for East Timor to have a significant period of autonomy—in some statements up to 10 years—before a referendum on independence. It is clear that these three people so involved in the movement for an independent East Timor felt that the safety of the East Timorese people was best ensured through a gradual process. When it was decided that the East Timorese should vote as quickly as possible on whether they wanted autonomy within Indonesia or complete independence, neither the United Nations or the Australian government acted to oppose this decision. In fact, the Prime Minister and the Minister for Foreign Affairs acted to expedite the process of independence. The consequence of that inappropriate action is now apparent to all.

The recognition by Xanana Gusmao of the potential for violence and the need for the internal security of East Timor to be established was unfortunately not shared by the Australian government. Indeed, it appears that US intelligence reports derived from Australian sources indicated that there was a very high risk of violence following the conduct of the ballot for independence. I believe that, with effective diplomatic endeavours, thorough planning and regard to appropriate risk assessments, much of the bloodshed in East Timor leading up to and following the independence ballot could have been avoided.

Due to the lack of foresight by this government and its apparent unwillingness to heed advice on the situation in East Timor, the Australian troops—a significant portion of the multinational force—are now entering a dangerous situation. They do so with bravery and with that certain matter-of-factness that often characterises Australian forces. I would like to repeat my heartfelt thanks to those people for their commitment to Australia and to wish each of them a very safe return to their families and friends. We need to urge the government to adequately resource and relieve these men and women. I also urge the government to rethink its very short-sighted policy of de-funding Radio Australia and to reinstate the broadcasts needed not only by our troops—members may have seen a few of them watching the footy the other day on television—but by those members of the Indonesian community who support our actions and who need to know what our position is.

I want to pass on my congratulations and my appreciation to all those Tasmanians who have written, emailed or attended rallies and vigils in Tasmania, in particular to those who organised a rally and vigil in Launceston last Friday. Unfortunately, this event was not incredibly well attended, but those who did attend have an incredible amount of regard and support for the people of East Timor. They have been involved in this issue for some time and expect an awful lot from this government.

In conclusion, it is very important that we must not kid ourselves that we are not culpable in this affair. The United Nations promised the East Timorese that we would be there before, during and after the ballot. Indeed, there were UN posters which contained a picture of the dove, the UN sign of peace, and said, `UNAMET—the prize is peace'. I support the motion before us, but I believe we owe it to those who have died to examine the process. This should not have happened and it should never happen again.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to be here tonight in support of the motion, but also to canvass a few of the issues around East Timor and what has occurred. It is true that the whole policy and the issues around East Timor have in many ways dominated Australian foreign policy over the last 25 years. I for one, amongst a number of other members, have been involved in demonstrations on these issues in years gone by. Certainly it is true to say that many on this side of the House have had concerns about East Timor policy over the last 25 years, often in a situation where we were critical of the policies of our own government. However, we can also agree that it has been an issue to which there is no easy solution. Recent events have shown that that is, in fact, the case.

speech.para: As we look through what has occurred over the last few months, we are now in a situation where there is a debate about what might have been if certain things had happened, and 20/20 hindsight has been used on a number of occasions in looking at the question of what policy actually was undertaken on a number of issues. Those issues focus on things such as: was the ballot for independence for the East Timorese people held too early; should there have been peacekeepers in place prior to the event; how and how well were the Americans involved in the formulating of options and their involvement in options around the question of what occurred; and where do we go from now?

I would conclude that there are a number of things which the government should be looking to in the future around the question of what occurred. Although 20/20 hindsight is something that none of us have, it is certainly true that there were a range of concerns raised about aspects of policy on East Timor. Certainly it is true that spokespersons on behalf of the opposition, and a number of commentators, had raised a number of these issues over time and suggested quite strongly that there were matters that needed to be taken up earlier than they were and probably more effectively than they were.

It is always hard in the foreign policy area to make judgments about how well a particular policy is pursued. It involves making judgments in an area where people often are involved in rewriting history after the event. However, as many academics have said, it is fair to say that there are issues there about the terms of engagement, about the Australian foreign minister and defence minister being involved earlier, and there are certainly issues about involving the United States at an earlier time and making sure that they were aware of the desperate situation.

It is also fair to say that since the results of the ballot were made known, the resultant carnage in East Timor, the ferocity of what has occurred and the degree of desperate action that has been taken by the militia in the context of what has occurred in East Timor have been a surprise to some of us. Only tonight on the news we saw more details about the level of death and destruction. New atrocities are appearing on a daily basis.

That leads to the issue of a human rights court and the need to have a war crimes process to ensure that the perpetrators of these crimes are brought to justice. This is going to take a long time. It is certainly something I am sure the government will be cognisant of and will move forward on as quickly as it can. I understand that there are difficult issues there that need to be addressed, but certainly those issues must be addressed if we are going to see a situation where those who did these acts in East Timor, and those who may do them in other parts of the world, understand that barbaric behaviour cannot be allowed to go unchecked.

One of the other issues that has come up and which has been an item for discussion over the weekend, and in particular today in question time, is the matter of the so-called Howard doctrine. I stress that the Prime Minister today in question time did seek to clear up a range of inconsistencies and concerns that had been raised about that policy, but there are some things that still need to be said and some issues that need to be taken up.

The Bulletin article that has been the basis of this matter was published five days ago and yet it took the Prime Minister until today to clarify some of those issues about being a regional policeman, or a Deputy Dog as some would say, for the United States in this area. You have got to ask yourself the question why he took so long to respond. I saw Admiral Barrie on the Sunday program yesterday and he was clearly struggling to avoid answers on that issue. He saw it as being outside his brief, but also he was clearly uncomfortable with the position the Prime Minister had taken. He knew full well the concern about our position within the region as an independent power.
I will quote an article in today's paper as an example of the commentary that the initial position has brought forward. Greg Sheridan in the Australian said:

Gaze out today on the rubble of what was once Australian foreign policy and weep. As Canberra races to find an ark of 1950s antiquity in which to carry its back-to-the-future Howard doctrine, the region has reacted with extreme hostility.

We have seen the reaction from a number of countries in the area. The problem with having a proper debate on some of these issues about our position in the region is that you often get into a `he said, she said' argument. You get a situation where particular issues are reinterpreted time and time again in order to try to remove any concerns or inconsistencies.

But it took five days to respond, five days to actually address the issue and clarify some of those concerns. We see in this particular position, however it has been redefined to this day, a fairly common thread that has run through this government on foreign policy issues and from this Prime Minister from a very early stage. It is an approach which harkens back to the days of empire in some respects. It is a variation on a theme where we can go forth and basically be a policeman or a great white Raj. I am not quite sure how you quite put it in these circumstances.

I think that is an issue of concern. It does miss a fundamental reality about today—and I don't want to get into a debate about whether we are Asian, from Asia or in Asia—that we need to be conscious of our position in this region geographically. We need to see ourselves as a nation that can engage within this region.

Indonesia, and a number of other regimes, have a democratic base that is not in common with our own nor are their actions to domestic security concerns what we, as a people, would endorse. These things raise concerns about how we involve ourselves in this region. The reaction that has come back to what was perceived as the Howard doctrine has been one of scorn and derision, pretty much universally within the region. This is a concern about how we position ourselves in the future. This has to be looked at very carefully. I hope the government will look at that very carefully because, if we are not in a situation where we can be seen to be working with our neighbours within the region while still having differing views on a range of issues, we will have problems on a trade and defence level and in putting ourselves forward as a proper contributor in the region. These are the sorts of things that this government particularly has to look at very closely.

I wish all the troops who are deployed in East Timor all the very best of luck. We are with you; we believe in what you are doing there. We believe it is important for this country, this region and for the world to see a proper and just settlement in East Timor, for the people to be protected and to have the right to build a new nation of their own. That is something that we all want to see. The job that they are doing there is so important. They have our very best wishes for a safe deployment, hopefully not for too long—but I suspect it will be for some time. I wish the very best to all those troops who are there.

talk.start.para: —I rise to support the Prime Minister's motion seconded and supported by the Leader of the Opposition. In Australia we believe in freedom and we believe in democracy. This issue is an awful lot about both of those concepts. I understand that, in much of the world, freedom and democracy have interpretations which would not be ours in Australia. I remind honourable members that we have the sixth oldest parliamentary democratic system in the world, exceeded only by Great Britain, the United States, Canada, Sweden and Switzerland—that is to say, countries that have kept their original democratic institutions, that have not been destroyed by military takeover, dictatorship or outright war.

speech.para: There is no question in my mind that East Timor has been a significant problem for the world community for a very long time. It has been a greater problem for the citizens who live on that half of that island. I would not pretend to know the answers to their problems nor would I pretend to know whether or not the Indonesian Prime Minister Habibie's decision to have a referendum or plebiscite on the issue of independence versus administration for autonomy as part of Indonesia was correct. It is not for me to say what is right for Indonesia. Some 25 years ago, I suspect that the whole world maybe made a wrong call when they let Indonesia attack East Timor; when they let them come in with armed intervention and take over a very small country that did not want to be under their control.

Nonetheless, we live with history as we do, and we will live with history for a very long time, because what is left today of East Timor is perhaps not worth owning except to those people who live there, who want to live there and who have been displaced from that country.

It was not that the Howard government sought independence for East Timor but rather that it sought some autonomy for a number of years, leading to the possibility of a referendum or a plebiscite on independence. Those on the other side who blame the Prime Minister, the Minister for Foreign Affairs and other members of the government, or indeed backbenchers like me, for the problems that we experience today in East Timor are just plain wrong. No-one created the problems in East Timor other than Indonesians themselves.

We recognise the importance of good relations with Indonesia. It is absolutely important that we continue to work towards gaining increasing good relations with that very major country, that major conglomerate of islands so very close to our north. It is self-evident that we cannot go our way in this part of the world without some relationship with Indonesia. It is better for us and it is better for the Indonesians if that relationship is positive. At the moment it is not good; I would be the last one to deny that fact.

It is obvious that the relationship has deteriorated since East Timor voted for its independence and since, apparently, members of the Indonesian armed forces encouraged the militants in East Timor to destroy the infrastructure of the country, murder many of the inhabitants and chase others to other islands of the archipelago. But, notwithstanding the military's actions, we can only assume the good intentions of the Indonesian government and the people of Indonesia, and we must work towards improving relations over the near and distant future.

We wish our troops in East Timor well. They go with our very best wishes and we wish them to stay out of harm's way. I would never wish anyone to have to go to war: I believe in peace. But I also know, realistically, that there are times when it is right to fight for what you believe in. Without putting too fine a point on it, the fact that the international community has decided that this is one of those times is highly appropriate. That those poor, gentle people in East Timor, suffering as they have over how many decades, should be put to the ultimate desecration by the militia and apparently by some Indonesian troops over recent weeks since they voted for independence, is beyond the pale.

It is highly appropriate that Australia leads the international force. It is highly appropriate that we asked for the international force and that we have asked for support from not only Asian nations but European and American nations as well. From my viewpoint, it is encouraging that that support came freely and willingly, and as the troops build up we will see, increasingly, different faces and different uniforms across the small bit of that island that is East Timor.

It is a difficult operation for the troops. I certainly do not pretend to be an expert on military operations or military affairs, but that mountainous island poses extreme difficulty for the international troops. They come under heavy pressure from the militant militia and others with weapons who would do them harm, and who want to destroy the international peacekeeping force for no other reason than to make sure that either they win or they simply destroy that which they were unable to win. That is very sad.

This is a difficult operation and I wish our troops well. I hope they come under no criticism and I hope they come to no harm. Australians send them with goodwill and with all our support, from every side of politics, from every colour, from every religion, from every country on earth. We send them to represent us in this international situation which we cannot control but where we wish, on a humanitarian level, to help people who deserve our help and our respect to maintain their lives, to rebuild their communities and infrastructure and to make a future for themselves now that they have said that they believe in freedom and they believe in democracy, as we believe in freedom and we believe in democracy.

I have no question in my mind, having watched television and listened to reports, that there have been extreme violations of human rights in that poor, small island. And they are extreme. The kinds of atrocities that have occurred are not minor violations of imprisonment or incarceration but violations that demean all of us as human beings, and I deplore those atrocities. I wish I could wipe them from my mind but I cannot. It is important that the United Nations, as the body from which we seek leadership in this issue, comes to grips with this problem, examines the violations of human rights that have occurred there and brings to justice those who have perpetrated the injustices.

This is a critical time for all of us. It is a critical time for our poor friends on that small island to our north. It is a critical time for us, in terms of our standing in the international community. I am confident that we will stand tall and proud, as will our East Timorese neighbours, at the end of the day.
Motion (by Mr Hawker) agreed to:
That further proceedings be conducted in the House.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Prime Minister, upon notice, on 9 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the former Tasmanian Liberal Government and the former member for Braddon provide him information about proposed magnesite mining and processing in Tasmania and related energy options for Bass Strait; if so, what information.

(2) Did he indicate to the former member for Braddon that (a) he would personally take an overview of the proposal and (b) Mr Bob Mansfield of the Government's special projects team would be asked to take a leading role in advancing the proposal.
(3) Is the proposed Crest Resources 51 billion magnesite project in Tasmania on the Government's special projects priority list; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The former Liberal state government and the former Member for Braddon both argued strongly for support of the project. I received information which was provided to the Commonwealth on the nature of the proposed investment and its importance to Tasmania.

(2) During the last federal election, the former Member for Braddon announced that the Major Projects Facilitator attached to my Office, Mr Bob Mansfield, would oversee the project and make sure there were no unnecessary delays or impediments in terms of satisfying Commonwealth government requirements. This announcement was cleared with my Office prior to release.
(3) The Minister for Industry, Science and Resources grated the proposal Major Project Facilitation status on 21 April 1999.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Long Term Operating Plan Concerns
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 801)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 154 (Hansard , 30 March 1999, page 4778), how many incidents where language differences have been a factor have been reported since March 1996.

(2) How often do Civil Aviation Safety Authority (CASA) inspectors conduct random inspections of foreign operators at their first port of call in Australia to assess the ability of the pilot in command to understand and speak the English language.
(3) How many random inspections referred to in part (2) have been conducted by CASA inspectors since March 1996.
(4) What percentage of foreign operators which have entered into Australia since March 1996 have been subjected to random inspections referred to in part (2).

(5) Do Air Operator's Certificates issued to foreign operators contain a condition that the pilot in command, and any other crew member making a radio transmission from the aircraft, must be able to read, speak and understand the English language; if so, are operators other than the pilot in command ever subjected to random inspections carried out by CASA inspectors; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) The Australian Transport Safety Bureau has advised that BASI has received sixty incident reports since March 1996 where language was identified as a factor. These reports included instances where the reporter referred to language as a factor and those where the Investigator has determined that language was a factor in the incident.

(2) As part of the international safety oversight program, CASA conducts inspections of two foreign operators per month. While these inspections are planned (and therefore not "random"), they are unannounced ie. the operator is not aware that they will occur. Additional unplanned inspections may be undertaken as a result of incident reports or information obtained from other sources.
(3) Eighty-six inspections have been carried out since the program commenced in October 1996.
(4) At present, seventy foreign operators hold Australian Air Operator's Certificates that permit them to conduct commercial flights into and out of Australian territory.

Thirty-nine operators conduct regular passenger flights into Australia and seven conduct regular cargo flights. Nine operators carry out only a few passenger or cargo flights per year, and fifteen have not visited Australia for some time.
Ninety-two per cent of the regular passenger operators and fifty-seven per cent of the regular cargo operators have been inspected on at least one occasion.

Thirty-three percent of the operators who visit Australia infrequently have been inspected, and occasional inspections have been conducted of operators who do not hold an Air Operator's Certificate but have received approval for one-off non-scheduled flights.
(5) Air Operator's Certificates issued to foreign operators contain a condition that states:

"The language for radio communications within Australian Flight Information Regions is English and for this purpose the pilot in command and any other crew member making a transmission from the aircraft must be able to read, speak and understand the English language."

CASA inspectors endeavour to speak to each member of the aircraft technical crew during an inspection to assess their ability to converse in the English language. This will include the Captain, the First Officer, and any other pilots carried as part of the operating crew and the flight engineer if carried.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Long Term Operating Plan
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 802)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No 157 (Hansard , 10 March 1999, page 3703), has progress been made to introduce a system which will result in Airservices Australia being advised of the reasons why pilots have had an operational requirement for other than the runway nominated in accordance with the Long Term Operating Plan (LTOP) at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport (KSA); if not, why not; if so, what are the indications which have been received by Airservices Australia in relation to this system.
(2) Will the system also record the number of times pilots have refused LTOP based landing directions at KSA; if not why not.
(3) If the answer to part (2) is yes, and the system has already been established, how many times have pilots refused LTOP based landing directions at KSA.

(4) What steps must be taken for Airservices Australia to obtain the information which I requested as to whether pilots have refused LTOP based take-off directions since it was implemented and will he direct Airservices Australia to take those steps.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Yes. Airservices Australia advises that it has introduced a reporting system under which operators whose pilots have required a "non duty" runway are contacted and are asked to provide Airservices Australia with reasons for their use of the "non duty" runway. The results so far show that it is overwhelmingly the departing or arriving long haul B747 aircraft that are requesting a "non duty" runway for operational reasons. Pilots' requests are for the use of the main north-south runway and departures are requiring the use of the runway more often than arrivals.

(2) The primary purpose of the "non duty" runway reporting system is to give an indication of the type of aircraft requiring a "non duty" runway, to determine whether there were other than operational reasons for pilots requesting such runway and to assist in the education of pilots on the operation of LTOP at KSA. The system does not therefore seek to record with absolute accuracy the number of times pilots have had an operational requirement for a runway other than the nominated runway.
See (2) above.

(4) I am advised by Airservices Australia that due to difficulties in clearly defining "non duty" runway use particularly during LTOP runway mode changes it would not be practical to develop a reporting system that would comprehensively and accurately record all "non duty" runway use.

subdebateinfo.title: Sydney (Kingsford Smith) Airport: Current Operating Plan Concerns
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 803)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: Further to question No. 1735 (Hansard , 28 August 1997, page 7369), will he direct the appropriate body to keep and maintain consolidated records in relation to complaints made by air traffic controllers employed at Sydney (Kingsford-Smith) Airport; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: Airservices Australia has advised that it currently maintains a mandatory (electronically submitted) air safety incident reporting system which is the primary vehicle for air traffic controllers to voice their concerns on any defined air safety incident. Within this system there is a function encouraging air traffic controllers to report "events", which are defined as those occurrences which do not fall within the definition of an incident but which may be cause for concern in certain circumstances.
Air traffic controllers may also report their concerns formally through either of two independent, confidential reporting mechanisms
- the Confidential Aviation Incident Report (CAIR) system managed by the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation (BASI); or
- the Safety Management Information System (SMIS) managed internally by Airservices Australia's Directorate of Safety and Standards.
The above systems are subject to formal registration, recording and any related issues are managed.

Additionally, there are always avenues for air traffic controllers to report their concerns or complaints through the standard management protocols. Airservices Australia advises that any issue raised to management is assessed and acted upon in a manner appropriate to the impact of the issue. Such issue would normally be responded to via a formal letter or e-mail and the response kept on file.

Airservices Australia management at Sydney also advises that it has an issues management policy which encourages controllers to raise concerns with management and management has undertaken to respond to concerns in writing.

subdebateinfo.title: Bureau of Air Safety Investigation: Report
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 805)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, upon notice, on 9 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Did the answer to question No 156 (Hansard , 11 February 1999, page 2632) in part state that International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) standard phraseologies have been adopted to the maximum extent possible; if so, will he give similar importance to the ICAO recommendation that compliance with published noise abatement procedures should not be required in adverse operating conditions such as when the crosswind component, including gusts, exceeds 15 knots; if not, why not.

(2) Will he amend the Australian Aeronautical Information Publication (AIP) Sydney noise abatement procedures so the use of runways is only allowable where there is a crosswind component of no greater than 15 knots; if not, why not.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question as follows:

answer.para: (1) Airservices Australia has advised that it fully accepts its International Civil Aviation Organisation (ICAO) obligations and has adopted ICAO recommendations on standard phraseologies to the maximum extent possible. However, Airservices Australia advises that ICAO recommendations recognise there are matters on which ICAO member states have different needs and requirements arising from differing local operating circumstances and that member states can adopt different practices to those recommended by ICAO without the need to file a difference (as is the required case with ICAO standards). The maximum crosswind criterion at Sydney Airport was increased to 25 knots in 1989 as a noise abatement measure in order to maximise departures over Botany Bay.
(2) Refer (1) response.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 24 August 1999:

question.para: (1) How many active reservists in the Australian Defence Force (ADF) are estimated to be (a) tertiary students, (b) unemployed, or (c) otherwise without employer provided superannuation coverage.
(2) What would be the estimated annual cost of the ADF making a superannuation contribution on behalf of active reservists equivalent to 7% of their ADF-provided pay and allowances.

talker.name: Scott, Bruce, MP
Mr Bruce Scott
talker.role: Veterans' Affairs; Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) (a) Approximately 11%.
(b) Approximately 11%.
(c) Figures requested are unavailable.
(2) Based on the figures available, it is estimated that it would cost Defence $1.5 million to make a 7% superannuation payment on behalf of active Reservists.

subdebateinfo.title: Employment of Scientific and Technical Enemy Aliens Scheme
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 868)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Justice and Customs, upon notice, on 24 August 1999:

question.para: (1) Was the Chifley Government involved in bringing suspected war criminals and Nazi party members to Australia as part of the Employment of Scientific and Technical Enemy Aliens scheme (ESTEA) between 1946 and 1951.
(2) Were the backgrounds of prospective scientists covered up and were the objections of the Commonwealth Investigation Service and normal security clearances ignored.

(3) Did the former deputy head of the Attorney-General's Department, Mr Andrew Menzies, give the ESTEA scheme a clean bill of health in his 1986 government report; if so, is the Minister able to say whether Mr Menzies was misled and that his 1986 assertions that proper procedures were followed is incorrect.
(4) Will the Government reopen the Special Investigations Unit and launch a full investigation into these allegations.

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Justice and Customs has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) Cabinet approved the Employment of Scientific and Technical Enemy Aliens scheme (ESTEA) in December 1946.

I am advised by my Department that it has been unable to establish that any allegations of war crimes were made against any persons who entered under the ESTEA scheme. However, some may have been former members of the Nazi Party.

(2) I am informed that nothing has been located on file to suggest that the backgrounds of prospective scientists were covered up nor that the objections of the CIS and normal security clearances were ignored. Those were matters that were reviewed by Mr Menzies in 1986.
(3) Yes. Mr Menzies was satisfied that appropriate security clearances had been obtained by those German scientists and technicians who entered Australia under the ESTEA scheme.
None of the available records indicate that Mr Menzies was misled.

Any allegations of substance concerning alleged war criminals which have come to light since the closure of the Special Investigations Unit have been referred to the AFP for investigation in the same way as any other alleged offence against the law of the Commonwealth.
If specific information identifying particular individuals overlooked by the Menzies review is forthcoming it will be investigated by the AFP.

subdebateinfo.title: Migration Review Tribunal: Backlog of Applications
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 883)

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, upon notice, on 25 August 1999:

question.para: (1) How long is the backlog of applications for review by the Migration Review Tribunal (MRT), accumulated since the amalgamation of the Immigration Review Tribunal and the Migration Internal Review Office.
(2) What is the breakdown of the backlog by (a) application category and (b) registry or MRT office.
(3) What criteria are being used to select and process the inherited backlog.
(4) Have criteria been established for the processing of new applications; if so, are these applications simply being added to the backlog.
(5) What are the estimated processing times for applications for review by (a) registry and (b) category.
(6) How many appointments have been made to the MRT, by registry, as at 25 August 1999.
